dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT: LAWRENCE is neatly tinting a map with water colour. He sits back to look at it, patiently, but withou A shadow falls across him and he looks up, interested. CLOSE SHOT: LAWRENCE's point of view of a basement window Outside, the lower half of a camel walks by. MED. SHOT. We now see that LAWRENCE is seated in a long narrow room, hardly more than a glorified passage. At eac a hole has been knocked high up in the wall and a massive of electric cables proceeds in from one to the other and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 12 13 14 Continued dimming the already inadequate light which comes through semi-circular windows high up in the wall of the basement are six drawing boards with pots of paint, brushes, T squ protractors, compasses, pens and ink, pencils, piles of r and whatever else cartographers need. Above the boards ha with metal shades, and before eath boardis a stool. At on these sits the only other OCCUPANT of the room, a SERGEAN

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (gloomily) Michael George Hartley, this is a nasty, dark little room.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: 'T's right.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: We are not happy in it.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (thinking of the trenches) ‘lam,

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Then you are an ignoble fellow.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: 'T's right. He lights a cigarette, throwing down the packet and box, ’ LAWRENCE watches him, and goes on with his work. Itis a relationship not uncommon in the Forces; the gulf of clas rank has. been bridged by means of a ritualised parody. T the sound of boots on stone floor. LAWRENCE looks up. CLOSE SHOT. The door opens and a chirpy CORPORAL enters with a folded newspaper. Beyond him we catch a glimpse of telephone exchange and a flight of stairs leading upwards the basement. MED. SHOT. The CORPORAL walks over towards LAWRENCE. The phlegmatic SERGEANT takes no notice at all.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Here is William Potter with my newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Here y'are tosh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [oO 14 Continued 3 LAWRENCE takes the paper, paying for it with a coin fro pocket.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quite simply) © Thanks. ) (back to the act) Would you care for one of Sergeant Hartley's cigarettes?

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Se orc, —- Ta. It is part of the game that no-one shall smile. The CORPO one of the SERGEANT's cigarettes as LAWRENCE unfolds his oO

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Is it there? 15 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE holds up the paper at the front p is in Arabic. He is instantly absorbed. The SERGEANT and CORPORAL regard him with the respect which everyone feels man with a passion, even uncomprehended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course itis. Headlines. o (grimly) . . But I'll bet it isn't mentioned in The Times. (he indicates) "Bedouin Tribes Attack Turkish Strong- hold". And I'll bet there’s no-one in the & . Whole of this Headquarters who even knows it's happened. (he throws down the paper) Or would care if he did. . 16 MED. SHOT. LAWRENCE finds their sympathetic, bovine © upon him and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Allow me to ignite your cigarette. lo He strikes one of the SERGEANT's matches and lights th po, CORPORAL's cigarette. Then, he extinguishes the match Ig — slowly closing his finger and thumb upon the flame, attentive the while. It is a trick the other two have evi | before but which evidently still fascinates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: qt ima 9 .

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 © 16 Continued

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (dispassionately) You'll do that once too often. It's only flesh and blood. LAWRENCE returns to his work, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Why, Michael George Hartley, you're a philospher.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: (amiably) You're barmy. CLOSE SHOT. The door opens and an M.P. SERGEANT enters. M.P. Mr. Lawrence? LAWRENCE (Off) (courteously) Yes? M.P. Flimsy, sir. He goes towards LAWRENCE. CLOSE SHOT. The CORPORAL sits down on his own stool, as t M.P. enters picture, hands the flimsy to LAWRENCE, and ex LAWRENCE unfolds the flimsy and his expression changes. T SERGEANT takes no notice, assuming it to be a routine ord some kind. LAWRENCE puts down the flimsy and takes his ha a nail driven into the wall within reach, and gets down f his face very still, his eyes excited. The CORPORAL is pr with a burning match which he proceeds to extinguish betw fingers.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: Ow! (indignantly) It damn well 'urts!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Certainly it hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 18 Continued

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: (cajoling) Well what's the trick then?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: The trick, William Potter, is not minding if it hurts. THE CAMERA IS PANNING with him on the way to the door. He opens it and turns.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: . Oh, if Captain Gibbon (he articulates the name . with special politeness) should enquire for me, tell him I've gone for a chat with the General. - He turns to go. 19 CLOSE SHOT. The SERGEANT and CORPORAL.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: (not looking up) Right you are, tosh.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: (with just a shade of : resentment) He's barmy. /

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: He's all right. : (he slips from his stool and glances at the flimsy) Good Lord, he has too.

dialogues.speaker: CORPORAL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Gone to see the General.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT. The Junior Officers' Club is a spacious room, high, and airy, once ornate, now stripped, but immaculate and orderly. One side is of glass and gives onto a courty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Continued floor is covered in bleached matting: on the walls are st engravings of old victories, dead Generals and living Roy furnished with a great many basket chairs of uniform patt It is arranged in symmetrical fours round small tables with clo unbleached linen. There is a bar and a billiard table in the foreground of Fans turn. At the bar are two or three OFFICERS. One or two OT sit at tables. TWO are preparing for snooker. Otherwise t is empty. Their voices are pleasant and well-modulated. place LAWRENCE appears in the background walking through the Cl alongside the glass screen. The SECRETARY (GIBBON) is chalking his cue at the billuar He is a CAPTAIN and wears a fierce moustache like a circu - master. The other OFFICER is also a CAPTAIN and is rais the triangular frame from the reds when the SECRETARY see LAWRENCE, frowns, surprised, and after a fractional hesit calls:

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Lawrence. : LAWRENCE veers over towards them; the SECRETARY continues with his cue until LAWRENCE is within a few paces of the

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be ... do you usually wear your cap in the Club? The SECRETARY 's tone is not hectoring, but on the contra low-pitched, to avoid needless embarrassment, and his wor e. quite accompanied by a serious little smile. LAWRENCE's tone wi OFFICERS will be nervously aggressive, whereas his tone w B.O.R.'s was comfortable, courteous, and even affectionat

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Always. LAWRENCE had in fact forgotten the cap and wishes very mu he had not. His eyes slide to take in the other OFFICERS talking. He relaxes deliberately.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (still mild, but not smiling) You're supposed to be on duty, aren't you? Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i @ 20 Continued ic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i (reproving) / Mustn't talk shop, Freddy. Not in the | Club. oO { The OFFICERS regard him not with animosity, but with de i . disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: ' NS ,
dialogues.text: ‘ ‘ LAWRENCE | Matter of fact, I'm just going for a pow- © wow with the General.

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (reasonably) I'm not asking as your superior, Lawrence, I'm asking as Secretary of this Club. (reasonably again) We don't want chaps in here when they should be on duty. (firmly) Where are you going, please? By way of answer, LAWRENCE, smiling knowingly, takes the and flicks it across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: . 21 CLOSE UP. The black hits the triangle sending the ba « : directions. 22 MED. SHOT. The CAPTAIN who all this time has been chal his cue with considerate indifference, looks up and says exasperation:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN
dialogues.text: I must s Say, Lawrence! : LAWRENCE looks at the littered table where the balls st . confusion, and the glitter leaves his face. ©

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Sorry! And he turns and goes, watched by EVERYONE. SECRETARY say c after him, not jeering but firmly:

dialogues.speaker: CO SECRETARY
dialogues.text: You' re aclown, Lawrence. © At this LAWRENCE turns and says, backing:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: =o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 23 24 25 26 il Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh well, we can't all be lion-tamers. And backs into a table at which a young LIEUTENANT of Yeo with a handsome face and buttered hair is drinking. CLOSE UP. A half-empty bottle of lager falls over on the spills onto the perfect breeches. CLOSE SHOT. The LIEUTENANT, with cruel restraint merely puts down his glass and looks at LAWRENCE.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Sorry. - CLOSE SHOT. An awkward pause. LAWRENCE hesitates. But there is nothing to be done. He goes. They all look after silence, the LIEUTENANT of Yeomanry steadily wiping his b with a handkerchief, the CAPTAIN starting to rearrange th The SECRETARY turns back to the table saying clearly:

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Pretentious oaf.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT. GENERAL MURRAY is one of those regulation officers whose pride is to appear more regulation than an His face is hard and shrewd, his expression exasperated. seated at his desk. On the wall behind him is an "Illustr News" type pen and ink sketch of heavy artillery on the W On a ledge under the picture is a collection of empty she varying sizes. GENERAL MURRAY is addressing DRYDEN, a donnish man with a pale, lined, lively face, wearing civi who at this moment has his back to us as he stands lookin window overlooking the gardens of the Headquarters.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I smell an intrigue! An intrigue between the Arab Bureau and a junior officer of my staff! A very junior officer, an insubordinate junior officer, an officer who, so far as I can gather, has proved markedly incompetent in a very junior post! DRYDEN turns from the window, smiling a little at the ref LAWRENCE's incompetence, and offers a smiling explanation  rn nm soo +s ae we et

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | © 26 Continued Ic

dialogues.speaker: I DRYDEN
dialogues.text: ; He wants to go to Arabia, sir. He strolls away from the window towards a chair in front Oo MURRAY's desk, the CAMERA TRACKING BACKWARDS with him ) into a medium shot of the two of them. We now see that | i carrying a copy of the Arabic newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm aware of that. He's made application © for a posting to Arabia once a month ever since he got here. Very well then, the Arab Bureau comes along and says, " we i want an Intelligence man in Arabia. We want you to second us a man in Arabia. jo We think it should be Mr. Lawrence." It's i an intrigue, Dryden, and I don't propose to let an over-weening, finicking, crass Lieutenant thumb his nose at his General Officer Commanding, and get away with it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i] He loosens the collar of his shirt as DRYDEN smiles ag in the chair.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (calmly quizzical) « It doesn't sound as though he'd be any great loss, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Now don't try that, Dryden. There's a principle involved. rr >

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: iO (suddenly quite sharp - i" but still calm) j There is indeed. He's no use here in Cairo : and he might be in Arabia. He knows his j stuff, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oC 28 CLOSE UP. MURRAY. He is a little put out by the mor aan this, which though a shade spinsterish is not less au a) that. He grumbles: oO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 28 Continued 13

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Knows the books you mean. ("books" is very contemptuous) I've already sent out Colonel Brighton - who is a soldier - and if Brighton thinks we should send them some small arms then we will. What more d'you want?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: There would be no question of Lieutenant Lawrence giving military advice, sir -

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: - My God I should hope not!

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: It's just that the Arab Bureau wants its own man on the spot sir, to...

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: (suspicious) To what?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: To make our own appraisal of the situation. DRYDEN spreads his hands deprecatingly as he says this, a who makes an almost childishly small request. But his eye ready for conflict - he speaks for the Bureau - and MURRA uneasy. This is a conflict which has been brewing for som 30 CLOSE UP. MURRAY. He looks away, fiddels with a ruler. Blurts out:

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I may as well tell you. It’s my considered opinion and that of my staff that any time spent on the Bedouin will be time wasted. They're a nation of sheep stealers! 31 CLOSE UP. DRYDEN. He raises and lets fall the newspape

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: They did attack Medina.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 31 Continued 32 CLOSE UP. 14 MURRAY (Off) And the Turks made mincemeat of them.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: We don't know that, sir. MURRAY.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: We know they didn't take it. A storm in a tea-cup, Dryden, a side-show ~ (he broods) If you want my own opinion, this whole theatre of operations is a side-show. The real war's being fought against the Germans not the Turks. Not here, but on the Western Front ... in the trenches! (his eyes glow and we see for a moment how he longs to be there organising mass attacks through mud) And your "Bedouin Army" or whatever it calls itself - would be a side-show of a side-show! 33 CLOSE UP. DRYDEN. He is smiling again.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Big things have small beginnings, sir. 34 CLOSE SHOT. MURRAY darts a quick look at him and rises

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: And does the Arab Bureau want a big thing in Arabia? If they rise against the Turks, does the Bureau think they're going to sit down quietly under us when this war's over?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: The Bureau thinks the job of the moment is to win the war.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: (flushing, walks back to his desk) Don't tell me my duty, Mr. Dryden.  2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 35 36 37 38 15 CLOSE SHOT. The door is opened bya STAFF MAJOR. Behind him we see LAWRENCE standing in the outer office. He move forward as soon as he is announced.

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR
dialogues.text: Lawrence, sir. MURRAY (Off) Send him in. LAWRENCE brushes past the MAJOR and walks into the room.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Good morning, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Salute! CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE comes to a halt near DRYDEN and salutes, very badly, his legs not quite together, and thr long glance at DRYDEN expecting approbation, but DRYDEN s his head quickly, somewhat to LAWRENCE's surprise. MED. SHOT. THE GROUP. MURRAY has been looking at LAWRENCE, ready to be enraged, but with something not unl caution, but he intercepts the look at DRYDEN and explode

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: If you're insubordinate with me, Lawrence, I'll put you under arrest!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (apparently crestfallen) It's my manner, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: (barks, suspicious) What?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My manner, sir. It looks insubordinate, but it isn't really. MURRAY is again baffled by his own lack of imagination an LAWRENCE's apparent innocence. He moves uneasily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 38 Continued 16

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I can't make out whether you're bloody bad-mannered or just half-witted.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (confidentially) I have the same trouble, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: (thumping the table) Shut up!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: The Arab Bureau seems to think you could be some use to them in Arabia. Why, I can't imagine. You don't seem able to perform your present duties properly.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (smiling, he quotes - not mockingly, but as dons do quote, en passant) "I cannot fiddle but I can make a great state from a little city."

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: _ (suspicious, barks) What?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (delicately helpful) Themistocles, sir. A Greek philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: I know you've been well educated, Lawrence; it says so in your dossier. He pushes back his chair, rises, and walks to a window. 39 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE and DRYDEN. LAWRENCE raises his eyebrows and smiles enquiringly at DRYDEN, but DRYDEN frowns and gestures with his hand that he is to simmer do

CLOSE SHOT. MURRAY standing looking out of the window. A swirl of dust blows by outside. MURRAY's face is dark w the extrovert's loathing of the sensitive and introspecti slowly and with great sincerity:

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: You're the kind of creature I can't stand, Lawrence ... but I suppose I could be wrong. All right, Dryden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MURRAY (Off) ++, You can have him for six weeks. LAWRENCE's face lights up, but almost immediately he comp himself. CLOSE SHOT. MURRAY has turned around eyeing LAWRENCE heavily.

dialogues.speaker: . MURRAY
dialogues.text: Who knows! It might even make a man of him. (in answer to a knock at the door) Come in! LONG SHOT. The door opens and the STAFF MAJOR enters excitedly with a sheaf of bills.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: What is it, Hawthorn?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR
dialogues.text: Navy signal, sir. The convoy's coming in tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: (real joy) Is that certain?

dialogues.speaker: MAJOR
dialogues.text: Yes sir ... there doesn't seem to be any artillery. MURRAY's joy changes to anxiety. He snatches the paper.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: There must be artillery! este ttmemtenee ne  18

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 43 Continued iO i DRYDEN and LAWRENCE have been forgotten. i : DRYDEN i (firmly) oO It's something of an expedition, sir. He : has got to get to Yenbo, find transport, 6 find the Arabs, and then get back. He fo5 . can't do that in six weeks. ° 1 © MURRAY | Two months then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i Three. | © MURRAY All right, three! Now let me do some work, Dryden. . And immediately his attention is back on the papers. ew a DRYDEN Thank you, sir. DRYDEN leaves, beckoning to LAWRENCE to follow, but : ‘ LAWRENCE remains. He addresses MURRAY's bent head. He i sincere and correspondingly awkward.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: : I'd like to say, sir, that lam grateful for .... © MURRAY Shut up and get out. 44 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. His expression is hurt, then vic resentful; then is replaced by his habitual protective mo © THE CAMERA PANS with him as he goes to the door and tur

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Sir! o 45 CLOSE SHOT. MURRAY andthe MAJOR. They both look up. ~ 46 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. He performs a slow-motion paro | CO of the regulation army salute and goes. lb  3 ve eoaie . “6 é oO o ad

dialogues.speaker: OO
dialogues.text: 19 47 CLOSE SHOT. MURRAY and the MAJOR. Even before the door has closed MURRAY is searching rapidly through the Bills He comes to the end and starts again, more and more frant Suddenly he cries out in real distress.

dialogues.speaker: MURRAY
dialogues.text: Oh, how can I fight a bloody war without bloody artillery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 48 CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. DRYDEN and LAWRENCE. THE CAMERA IS TRACKING on a CLOSE SHOT of DRYDEN. LAWRENCE runs up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh, Shabash, Dryden! DRYDEN avoids him and continues walking.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (reproving) He's not a bad chap, Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: . LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No he's not a bad chap, he's a fool. (grins in anticipation) How did you do it? DRYDEN again avoids him and goes on walking.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: You might better ask me why I bothered to. At. this LAWRENCE falls into step beside him, and althoug words are still flippant his face begins to assume its ex stiff and bitter withdrawal.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Because I'm the man for the job.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (looking straight ahead) I just wonder about that.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Of course I'm the man for the job. What is the job, by the way?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (pausing beside a door) Find Prince Feisal. DRYDEN opens the door and they enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT. This is a room at once similar to but utterly different from GENERAL MURRAY'S. It is elegantly furnishe carpeted, the room of a cultivated xenophile. There are p ancient desert monuments and fragments of carving.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Good. And when I've found him?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Find out what kind of man he is. Find out - (his gaze wanders somewhat) - what his intentions are. I don't mean his immediate intentions - that's Colonel Brighton's business, not yours. I mean his intentions in Arabia altogether. LAWRENCE appreciates the significance of this. He walks a little and comes to rest with his hand on a fragment of s

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh that's nice... DRYDEN agrees. LAWRENCE puts down the piece of stone.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Where are they now?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Anywhere within 300 miles of Medina. They're Hashemite Bedouins, they can cross 60 miles of desert in a day. LAWRENCE throws back his head in silent rapture.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh, thanks Dryden. This is going to be fun!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 21 49 Continued 50 51 52

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Lawrence, only two kinds of creature get ‘fun’ in the desert, Bedouins ... and - (his gaze wanders round the photographs of silent sun-~ scorched figures and the fragments of stone) ~ gods. And you're neither. Take it from me for ordinary men it’s a burning fiery furnace. DRYDEN is irritably tapping a black Russian cigarette for LAWRENCE steps forward, takes a box of matches and lights him.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (very quietly) No, Dryden, it's going to be fun. ' The set intensity of his expression is in utter contradic words. CLOSE UP. DRYDEN. He looks from the burning match in LAWRENCE's fingers to LAWRENCE's face.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (rather sourly) It is recognized that you have a funny sense of fun. CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE. He smiles and raises the flame to his lips. He bows it out in the normal manner,

dialogues.speaker: SUNRISE IN THE DESERT
dialogues.text: A series of shots taken with an under-cranked camera so t change from grey dawn to brilliant sunlight is speeded. T audience should be unaware of the trick process, but from appearance of the sun over the horizon and the casting of shadow there should be a constant sense of movement as th rises higher and higher and the shadows grow shorter and Prominent in the composition of almost every shot should footprints of two camels. We do not see the actual camels the series of under-cranked shots are finished and we

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 22 53 CLOSE SHOT. THE SUN, now a searing white. oN

54 LONGSHOT. A brilliantly lit desert vista of sand and r tiny figures of two MEN on camels appear over a distant r 55 CLOSE SHOT. The camels come toahalt. They are ridden b LAWRENCE, who is dressed in regulation British uniform, a TAFAS, his Arab guide, who wears the robes of a Hazimi of Salem. The two MEN scan the horizon. 56 LONGSHOT. A vast romantic landscape of sand, rock and 57 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE AND TAFAS. Almost involuntarily LAWRENCE takes in a deep breath of air.

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: Here you may drink, one cup. LAWRENCE unstraps a tin army mug and fills it from his wa bottle. He is about to drink and then stops.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You do not drink?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ! No. i iy LAWRENCE I will drink when you do. LAWRENCE begins to return the ‘water to the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: © (grunts and shrugs) Iam Bedu.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 58 LONG SHOT. A MUD FLAT UNDER FLOATING DUST. (But the mud flat should be broken by rocks and not comparable to Nefud mud flat later, and the dust not comparable to eith opaque wall of the dust-storm nor the weird effect of Sin is, as it were, a mere introduction to and explanation of phenomenon. ) 59 MED. TRACKING SHOT. LAWRENCE and TAFAS emerge well powdered from one small cloud into clarity. TAFAS ties hi headcloth round his mouth. LAWRENCE spits out dust while TAFAS is doing this and TAFAS looks at him. They are obsc ve again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: eo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 60 61 62 63 64 23 MED. TRACKING SHOT. They emerge. TAFAS offers to LAWRENCE a bit of rag, intimating in mime that he should over his mouth. LAWRENCE hesitates. They are obscured aga MED. TRACKING SHOT. They emerge, LAWRENCE with the rag tied over his mouth. Camera pans with them. LONG SHOT. They. ride away from us towards the next cloud distantly drifts down towards them.

For a m LAWRENCE remains in the saddle easing his aching back, th anxious to hide his discomfiture, he climbs stiffly out o only to find that standing is even more painful. TAFAS ha his water skin and brings it to LAWRENCE.

A wide and empty plateau with mountains in the distance. CLOSE SHOT. TAFAS points out ahead, but seeing nothing, LAWRENCE unslings an old pair of binoculars and raises th his eyes. LONG SHOT (BINOCULAR EFFECT) A caravan of four camels moving across the plateau towards the mountains. CLOSE SHOT. TAFAS is looking at them intently, but findin LAWRENCE's regard upon him he gives a quick explanatory g says, with the off-handedness of one belittling his own a his own comfort.

Saddles and saddle bags piled before LAWRENCE and TAFAS on the other side of the fire. CUT BACK from this a CLOSE SHOT. TAFAS is eating a fist full of rancid mutton LAWRENCE is eating thin arrowroot biscuits which he extra from their packet and eats as neatly as if he were in a v Between them on the sand are LAWRENCE's shining tin mug, whatever nasty receptacle such a person as. TAFAS might u Silence prevails. TAFAS' eyes flick intently from time to LAWRENCE's revolver on the pile of LAWRENCE's equipment. (CLOSE SHOT on this) LAWRENCE from time to time, watches brisk progression of fat from TAFAS' hand to mouth. His e is in no way disgusted. He is wondering if he could do it he takes up his mug. It is empty. TAFAS quickly offers hi which is half full. It is rimmed with mutton fat. LAWRENC gently rejects it. TAFAS looks at it for a moment and rep on the ground. LAWRENCE disapproves of himself. TAFAS addresses liis jaws to the mutton and his eyes to the rev

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Take it.

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: (stops eating and looks at LAWRENCE. As one who explains the nature of a commercial contract) I, take you to Lord Feisal. Then you give it to me.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (nods to show his comprehension) Take it now. He gives the pistol to TAFAS, who, eyes shining, wipes hi on his clothes and takes it reverently as though it were he a connoisseur. Wordlessly he thrusts it into his belt. at LAWRENCE with a complex of emotions struggling beneath rudimentary features. He takes up his fat and has a brilliant idea. He holds it but his smile vanishes as he remembers the incident of th laughs deprecatingly at the mutton...  73 14 75 26 Continued

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: Bedu food. (... and rather sadly draws it back again) LAWRENCE thrusts out his hand and takes apiece and puts ‘ mouth, watched anxiously by TAFAS. There is no comedy, an from the steely concentration of his face we see that the indeed mortified.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: (very pleased, thrusts out the fat) More? LAWRENCE gravely takes some more.

dialogues.text: EXTREME LONG SHOT. (HELICOPTER) The desert is nowa firm and level plain. At first we see nothing but the swe empty desert, then we perceive two tiny moving objects fa moving towards the CAMERA. The CAMERA begins to descend towards them, and as they increase in size, we see two sh two camels, two RIDERS. The CAMERA keeps boring in, and w identify LAWRENCE and TAFAS cantering along at a good cli CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. LAWRENCE is still awkward on his mount and TAFAS is giving him riding tips as they move al LAWRENCE's confidence grows, and the CAMERA pans and trac with him as he urges the camel into a gallop. The camel d an erratic circle which brings LAWRENCE back alongside TA LAWRENCE knows he has done well, and raises his eyebrows, amused by his own greed for praise.

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: (genuinely approving) I think we reach Masturah Well - tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: And from Masturah Well to Lord Feisal's camp, one day more.

(HELICOPTER) The CAMERA pulls back and up, as the canter becomes a gallop - higher and higher - until t FIGURES, now moving away from CAMERA, are lost to view. CLOSE SHOT. The white hot sun of noon. He grunts and points.

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: The Well. (but he is less interested in this than in whatever else he is again scanning for) CLOSE SHOT. A brilliant circle of blue sky framed in blac The faces of LAWRENCE and TAFAS appear on the edge of the circle. A bucket hurtlés down towards CAMERA, and with a splash, breaks the reflection in the still water at the b well. MED. SHOT. The top of the well is situated on the edge of flat. As TAFAS begins to haul up the bucket he glances ca round the horizon. . LAWRENCE, noticing this, does the sa

dialogues.text: eS 83 84 85 86 87 88 28 Continued they see nothing. TAFAS regains the bucket, pours some wa LAWRENCE's tin cup, then raises the bucket to his own lip both drink.

dialogues.text: Good?

dialogues.text: (with a half-smile) It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: TAFAS
dialogues.text: (the idea is new to him, but he looks into his bucket, catches on, and with the patronizing indulgence proper between two civilized gentlemen for the weakness of the primitive) This is a Harith Well. (with hypocritical regret) The Harith are a dirty people. (he drinks greedily) With another look round the horizon he goes over to a sma and pours out the remainder of the water for the camels. camels drink, LAWRENCE strolls over to a little patch of lazily sits watching TAFAS as he returns to the well and bucket into it. A splash echoes up from below. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE begins to whistle to himself. (The Man Who Broke the Bank"’) .as he drifts off into a little The sound of the bucket is heard bumping up the side of t then it stops. There is a moment's silence followed by a splash. LAWRENCE looks up. CLOSE UP. TAFAS is standing stock still looking out over mud flat. CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE turns to see what he is looking at. LONG SHOT. A little dust cloud is approaching at a distan about half a mile, floating above the mirage. MED. SHOT. LAWRENCE rises, and slowly goes over to TAFAS. They stand together staring out over the flat.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Turks? TAFAS does not answer. LONG SHOT. The blob is now recognisable as a horse or a c but elongated, as if on stilts by the mirage. CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE AND TAFAS. A moment's pause.

dialogues.text: Bedu. Without looking at LAWRENCE, he hurries off. MED. SHOT. As TAFAS leaves LAWRENCE and goes over to his camel the approaching FIGURE out on the mud flat is now c as an ARAB mounted on a camel. CLOSE UP. TAFAS unhitches his gun from the side of the ca and keeping close into animal, stands still, waiting ... LONG SHOT. The approaching STRANGER is now quite near... He wears a black hooded cloak with a black cloth drawn ac face. CLOSE SHOT. TAFAS is standing in the foreground of pictur while LAWRENCE waits, puzzled and apprehensive by the wel TAFAS masks his face with his headcloth.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Who is he? TAFAS cocks his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (sharply) Tafas: QUICK CLOSE SHOT. TAFAS, masked. His eyes frightened. Deaf to LAWRENCE. QUICK MED. SHOT. At a distance of some 125 yards the STRANGER is tapping his camel into a kneeling position. A reaches the ground he draws his rifle from the saddle hol

dialogues.text: Tafas, let me - CLOSE SHOT. With a sudden movement TAF AS steps out from side of his camel, raises his pistol and fires. MED. SHOT. The STRANGER drops to the ground behind his ca There is another shot. TAFAS remains as still as a statue foreground of picture. CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE, frozen in place, numbed by the unexpe eruption of violence. LONG SHOT. The three MEN remain completely still. Then, TAFAS' gun falls to the ground with a clatter, and very s sags at the knees and crumples into a heap beside it. LAW runs over to the body. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE stands looking down at the dead man, and then raises his eyes to the mud flat. . : LONG SHOT. The STRANGER rises to his feet, reloads his ri and mounts his camel. CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE goes down on his haunches by TAFAS, keeping his eyes on ALI. MED. SHOT. LAWRENCE stands with his back to CAMERA in the foreground of picture. In the background the STRANGER slowly towards him and finally comes to a halt on the oth the dead man. After a glance to make sure that TAFAS is d thrusts his rifle into the saddle holster, unwinds his he leaps gracefully to the ground. He is a handsome young ma about LAWRENCE's age; an impressive figure in both bearin costume. He picks up the pistol. He examines it. ALI © Is this pistol yours, English?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No, his. So ALI stuffs it complacently into his own waistband and the well followed by his camel. He picks up the tin mug w lying on the wall of the trough.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: His?  31 106 Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Mine.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (as one who confers a compliment) Then I will use it. He scoops a little water from the trough and does so, LAW turns TAFAS onto his back.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: He is dead. LAWRENCE leaves TAFAS and approaches ALI.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes. Why?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: This is my well.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I have drunk from it.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (politely) You are welcome. They look at one another. Neither of them frightened but mutual incomprehension.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (comforting) He was nothing, English.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Then why kill him?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: He was nothing. The well is every- thing. And it is mine. I am Sherif Ali Ibn El Kharish.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (this is real news evidently, and makes LAWRENCE's mood more thoughtful) I have heard of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 32 CD 106 Continued “O i

dialogues.text: | Oo LAWRENCE i (indignation rising . spontaneously) ‘ I had not heard you were a murderer.

dialogues.text: (looks at TAFAS) (looks at LAWRENCE)

H cliffs tower above sparkling white sand and give the land atmosphere of incredible grandeur and beauty. 109 MED. SHOT. His camel grazes a few yards behind. 110 LONG SHOT. The distant figures of LAWRENCE and his tw camels from the COLONEL's viewpoint. 111 CLOSE SHOT.. LAWRENCE hears a parade-ground voice sho his name. He halts his camel and looks around. From the s of the rocks in the far back ground, the figure of the CO now mounted on a camel, comes out into the sunlight.

When he speaks it is rapidly who knows his own mind and has something on it. His name BRIGHTON. He rides up alongside LAWRENCE into a TWOSHOT.

dialogues.text: (hostile) I've been waiting for you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (surprised) Did you know I was coming?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: I knew someone was’ coming. Feisal told me.  ;

dialogues.text: © poe

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (interested) How did he know?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Not much happens within fifty miles of Feisal that Feisal doesn't know. I'll give him that. No escort?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My guide was killed at the Matsurah Well.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (alert) Turks? ‘ LAWRENCE No, an Arab.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (with real distaste, gloomy) Bloody savages ...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (cool) This is Wadi Safra isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Yes, they're over there. (indicating with a jerk of the head an evident declivity into which we cannot see. Then, as LAWRENCE is eagerly about to move forward, he checks him flatly) Just one moment, Lawrence. (irritably curious; his sense of professional etiquette is outraged) Now ~- who sent you?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I've been seconded to the Arab Bureau.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (his face clears. This has explained all) O-o-oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 35 112 Continued BRIGHTON (Cont) (the exclamation demonstrates his relief that LAWRENCE is in such a weak position as that) And what are you to do for the Arab Bureau? (a thousand Mess Room jokes are his authority for this attitude of patronizing amusement)

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (explicitly earnest and polite in ratio to BRIGHTON's implicit rudeness) . It's rather vague actually, sir, I'm to “appreciate the situation’. The parody of the Public School subaltern does not go unn BRIGHTON looks at him cautiously, but LAWRENCE's face is studiously innocent.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (grunts) That won't be difficult, the situation's bloody awful. (he digs irritably in the sand with a bit of stick) Their morale - if they ever had any morale, which I doubt - the Turks knocked it out of them in front of Medina, : _ (the irritation is replaced by abrooding sadness) with howitzers. They're fading away by dozens every night. And what I want to say to you is this: (he recites with considerable dignity his simple creed) Wherever you are, and whoever you are "with" you are a British Serving Officer. And here's anorder. When we get into that camp, you'll keep your mouth - shut. D'you understand what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) Yes sir, I understand what you're saying. (it is impudently equivocal, and has no trace of obedience)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 36 112 Continued

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (crisply, throwing away his stick and preparing to rise) You'll make your appreciation and get back to ~ And then, crouched springily on his heels, he freezes and and the vitality drains from his face. The organ note of aircraft approaches and his eyes are haunted as he utters soldier's prayer.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Oh my God, not again... The noise gathers, two explosions set the cliffs thunderi BRIGHTON and LAWRENCE rush to control their panic- -stric animals and look up as: : 113 LONG SHOT. A Turkish bi-plane shoots upwards from beh cliff, climbing steeply. The CAMERA pans with it as it ro overhead and banks into a sharp turn. 114 CLOSE UP. BRIGHTON and LAWRENCE turn around as they h the sound of a second engine. 115 LONG SHOT. Another plane roars over the cliff-top. 116 CLOSE SHOT. The camels buck and rear. BRIGHTON gets h under control, then LAWRENCE, who is looking up at: 117 LONG SHOT. The first plane completes its turn and goe shallow dive. The CAMERA pans with it until it disappears the cliff. 118 CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. LAWRENCE and BRIGHTON riding for the camp. BRIGHTON is talking vehemently - to himself rat than LAWRENCE - and glaring straight ahead.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: I've told him! God knows I've told him! "Move South" I've said, ‘''You're still in range!'' They simply will not realize what modern weapons do! 119 LONGSHOT. The screen is obscured by a cloud of drifti anddust. As it clears, a large Bedouin camp of some one h black tents is disclosed - now a scene of absolute pandem chaos. Amidthe casualties, MEN struggle to recapture loos animals and WOMEN search for their children, while chicke

The diving plane. 121 MED. SHOT. BEDOUINS scatter to left and right - out o the bombing run. 122 MED. SHOT. The plane swoops overhead. A bomb plummets downwards. 123 MED. SHOT. A tent disappears inthe flash of an explos 124 MED. SHOT. The plane sweeps away over a dune. Its sha races up to meet it on the crest and it vanishes over the 125 MED. SHOT. He rides towards CAMERA against the strea MEN and animals, wheeling his horse in an effort to calm He shouts as he rides.

A flash of the plane as its machine-gun op 129 CLOSE SHOT. FEISAL shoots vainly at the sky as the no engine deafens him, a line of bullets lash the sand behin the black shadow of the plane sweeps over and leaves him can turn to shoot again. 130 LONG SHOT. The plane sweeps away over the dust-laden its machine gun firing among the panicked BEDOUINS, who r every direction. Fo eerie

dialogues.text: so 181 CLOSE SHOT. FEISAL, his pale face contorted with rage his rifle at the retreating plane in an impotent gesture The approaching drone of the second plane makes himturn. machine gun opens fire. His horse rears. !

The shadow of the plane sweeps across the FEISAL beats his mare into a gallop and, flat out, his wh streaming behind him, he chases the dark shadow in a mad hopeless race. As the plane rapidly draws away he pulls u horse. 134 CLOSE SHOT. Surrounded by swirling dust, FEISAL is a tragic figure as he sits bolt upright on his trembling fo mare staring after the plane. 135 LONG SHOT. The two planes fly away into the distance. 136 CLOSE SHOT. As the drone of the planes dies away, so droops in the saddle. In the background the shattered cam life. MEN and WOMEN run to and fro, swiftly loading their ings onto pack-camels. FEISAL is absorbed in his own desp gazing down at the ground. After a few moments he braces as one who prepares to shoulder once again an intolerable He throws back his head and assumes a public face, but at gaze is arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 137 CLOSE SHOT... LAWRENCE looks down at him from a blank frame, with compassion certainly but more, with devouring 138 CLOSE SHOT. FEISAL looks up at him; his head slightly enquiringly.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (straight-forwardly interrogative - no "significance" please) Who are you? 189 CLOSE SHOT. BRIGHTON ina blue frame.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Lawrence, sir, seconded to the Arab Bureau. This is a bloody mess sir. We'll have to move south - 140 CLOSE SHOT. FEISAL looking up at BRIGHTON. He interru with the savagery of his self-reproach.  Lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 39 140 Continued

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Yes, yes, Colonel - fifty miles south - you were right and I was wrong. (his gaze shifts; he is looking at LAWRENCE _ and as though to him he says) We must take some thought for the wounded ... 141 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE as before. On SOUND TRACK BRIGHTON says: BRIGHTON (Over) We can take care of them at Yenbo sir. FEISAL (Over) If they can get to Yenbo. BRIGHTON (Over) (impatient) They can hardly come with us sir! 142 CLOSE SHOT. FEISAL looking up as before.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: No. They must try to reach Yenbo. ‘... Lieutenant - ? 143 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE as before.

dialogues.text: You understand Lieutenant Lawrence my people are ... unused to explosives and... machines... (he gazes about) First the guns ... now this... He is suddenly choked with emotion, turns on his heels an towards the scattered tents, walking. An ARAB takes his h which he has forgotten, and leads it after him.

dialogues.text: 146 EXTREME LONGSHOT. NIGHT. A great Bedouin caravan, wit their flocks and herds, winds out from the high cliffs an the open desert.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 147 LONG SHOT. DAY. The caravan is now sprawled out over bleak and featureless terrain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: his orderly, are riding several yards in front of LAWRENC with a map case on his knee, is noting the course of the Surrounding the three EUROPEANS is a moving mass of goats sheep, camels, WOMEN on foot and in howdahs, CHILDREN, WARRIORS, and baggage camels - a Biblical scene of Exodus 149 CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE raises the compass to his eyes and through it. 150 MED. SHOT. As seen through the markings of the compas CAMERA tracks behind the upright figure of FEISAL mounted his white mare and flanked by his two negro SLAVES anda STANDARD BEARER. 151 CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE lowers the compass and marks a pos onthe map. Hearing a sudden burst of shouting and laughte looks up. 152 MED. TRACKING SHOT. From behind a forest of marching legs an infuriated GOATHERD is shouting at two BOYS in th ground of picture. One of the BOYS is trying to ride a bu protesting ram, while the other, roaring with laughter, i keep him on. The ram eventually throws the RIDER on to th ground just as the GOATHERD springs out and proceeds to l them both with his stick. The BOYS escape among the camel to be met by another series of blows from the RIDERS. The CAMERA tracks with them down the line until they finally peaceful haven beside LAWRENCE. For a few paces they marc silence rubbing their tender backs, then, with a winning DAUD, the tougher of the two, looks up at LAWRENCE.

dialogues.speaker: DAUD
dialogues.text: (miming) Cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: yo

dialogues.text: 41 152 Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Sorry. (he spreads his hands. Then returns to his map) DAUD. looks up, interested, but the other imp, FARRAJ, nu and points to the two RIDERS ahead. They run forward out picture. 158 MED. TRACKING SHOT. BRIGHTON and JENKINS. The two BOY appear on either side of JENKINS' camel.

dialogues.speaker: DAUD
dialogues.text: Cigarette, your excellency?

dialogues.speaker: JENKINS
dialogues.text: 'Umph off! FARRAJ looks up at the CORPORAL with his soft swimming ey and raises his hands in a gesture of prayer.

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: Please, your excellency. Just one for two. The CORPORAL relents and throws down a cigarette packet. BOYS leap on it, only to find that itis empty. The CORPOR laughs. There is an exchange of looks between the two BOY the CAMERA drops back with them as they take up a positio immediately behind the CORPORAL's camel. With the deftnes long practice, FARRAJ daintily lifts the camel's tail and rams his stick home. The camel roars and takes off. 154 CLOSE SHOT. BRIGHTON, shouting after the CORPORAL.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Hold it, Jenkins! 155 CLOSE SHOT. JENKINS falls to the ground with a thud. 156 CLOSE SHOT. DAUD and FARRAJ walking along with studie ‘innocence. They hear someone laughing and turn. 157 CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE sees the two imps looking at him, checks his laughter. 158 MED. SHOT. Taking advantage of his appreciation, the BOYS fall in beside LAWRENCE's camel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C) 158 Continued 42

dialogues.speaker: DAUD
dialogues.text: Aurens ?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Aurens.

dialogues.speaker: DAUD
dialogues.text: You have no orderly.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I don't need an orderly.

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: (considers this) No? We can do everything - light fires - cook food - wash clothes -

dialogues.speaker: DAUD
dialogues.text: ~ yes everything.

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: It will be very nice for you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I can't afford it. © This is unanswerable. The BOYS grimace sympathetically LAWRENCE urges his camel forward out of picture. We stay the two BOYS looking about for fresh worlds to conquer.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 159 LONG SHOT. SUNSET. The new camp has been set up benea protecting ring of smooth rocks and high banks of sand at a remote plateau. The smoke of the fires rises straight i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and.one by one, lights appear in the largest and most cen Bedouin tents. On the heights above the camp, the tiny fi SENTRIES are silhouetted against the soft glow of the sun scene of great tranquility after the noise and bustle of sequences. : 160 LONG SHOT. From their angle, the camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 161 MED. SHOT. INT. FEISAL's tent. Though large, it is a black tent like the others, very sparsely "furnished", th is essential. Present are FEISAL, BRIGHTON, LAWRENCE and RECITER, to whom they are listening, BRIGHTON with a gent self-control which shrieks impatience, FEISAL head back, closed, LAWRENCE head down, face hidden.  eo 43 161 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RECITER
dialogues.text: ‘ Recite then as much of the Koran as may be easy to you. God knoweth that there be some among you sick while others travel through the earth and others do battle in His cause. Recite therefore as much as may be easy. And seek ye forgiveness of God. Verily God is forgiving, merciful. During this recital (which can of course be lengthened or necessary) ALI enters back to CAMERA seen by FEISAL whose - flick open, unseen by LAWRENCE or BRIGHTON, who face FE When the recital is finished.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Greetings, Ali. LAWRENCE and BRIGHTON turn surprised, LAWRENCE's expressi changes. With him, we recognize ALI.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (salaaming to FEISAL) My lord.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (a curt greeting) Sherif. ALI salaams silently to BRIGHTON. His hostile eyes return LAWRENCE. FEISAL claps‘his hands. ALI sits, not taking hi from LAWRENCE.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Lieutenant Lawrence, you have met Sherif Ali, I think.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (very dry) Yes my lord. In answer to FEISAL's clap a SERVANT appears and serves A with coffee, while:

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: And now Selim, "The Brightness".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: “eB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 44 161 Continued

dialogues.speaker: RECITER
dialogues.text: By the noon day brightness and by the night when it darkeneth, thy Lord hath not forsaken thee neither hath He been displeased. BRIGHTON exhibits impatience when the RECITER recommences FEISAL, seeing this, smiles gently, lays a hand on the RE wrist and finishes for him:

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: And surely the future shall be better for thee than the past -

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: - And in the end shall your Lord be bounteous to thee and thou be satisfied. 162 REACTION SHOT. BRIGHTON surprised, FEISAL surprised a pleased.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (looking at LAWRENCE) So? 163 REACTION SHOT. ALI's eyes flick suspiciously from FEI LAWRENCE, they smiling at one another. FEISAL takes in AL rampant Bedouin, BRIGHTON, European couchant. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Yes, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: I want a decision, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: You want me to fall back on Yenbo, Colonel.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Well you're not doing much good here sir! ... Sorry to rub it in sir, but - (bursting out; he has been over this ground a dozen times) We can't supply you here sir!

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: You could supply us through Akaba!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7 45 f O 163 Continued

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (astonished) Akaba! (angry) 9° Oh well if you can get hold of Akaba sir of course we can supply you. But you can't!

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: You could.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: : (incredulous) You mean the Navy? The Turks have lo twelve inch guns at Akaba sir - can you _ imagine what that means?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (heavily; dejected) Twelve inches. Yes, I can imagine. be . o BRIGHTON (more gently) Put that out of your mind sir; the Navy's got other things to do. ww a)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: | Ah yes. Protecting the Suez Canal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 (as one who states Me the obvious) i The one essential sector of this Front is and must be the Canal. You see that sir, surely? oO FEISAL I see that the Canal is an essential British interest. It is of little consequence to us.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: CG I must ask you not to talk like that sir. . The British and Arab interests are one ‘ and the same.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Possibly. 0 ALIlaughs sharply. BRIGHTON is disgusted.  163 Continued

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Upon my word sir you're ungrateful. Fall back on Yenbo and we will give you equipment! We will give you arms, advice, training, everything:

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (quickly) Guns?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: A modern rifle for every man.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (passionately) No: Guns! Artillery! Guns like the Turkish guns at Medina!

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (lounging, sneering) Yes; give us guns; and keep the training.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Your men need training far more than guns sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (laughs) The British will teach the Bedouin how to fight?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: We will teach them Sherif Ali, to fight a modern mechanized army! LAWRENCE makes an involuntary movement, suppresses ‘it, b

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Lieutenant? What do you think of Yenbo?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I think it is far from Damascus. . } FEISAL and ALI react to this. So does BRIGHTON, alarmed

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: We'll have you in Damascus sir, never fear -  wes © ot

dialogues.speaker: AT
dialogues.text: 163 Continued

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (scanning LAWRENCE with interest) Have you been in Damascus, Mr. Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes my lord.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: It is beautiful, is it not?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Very. Neither ALI nor BRIGHTON likes this rapport. ALI sits up, a pole; this STRANGER must be watched. BRIGHTON says, qui but compellingly:

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: That'll do, Lawrence. (sternly, to FEISAL) Dreaming won't get you to Damascus, sir. (kindly, persuasively) But discipline will. While BRIGHTON goes on, cut to ALI and LAWRENCE in silent frontation, cutting back to BRIGHTON only for the last tw

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Now look sir, Great Britain is a small country - much smaller than yours. Small population compared with some. It's small but it's great. And why - ?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Because it has guns!

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Because it has discipline!

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Because it has a Navy. Because of this the English go where they please and strike where they please, and this makes them great.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Right. ve

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163 Continued 48 FEISAL looks to him again. At once the storm breaks.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Lawrence that'll do! (quick, before FEISAL can speak) Lieutenant Lawrence is not your Military Advisor sir!

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: But I should like to hear his opinion. LAWRENCE opens his mouth. BRIGHTON jumps down it. FEISAL remains absolutely unmoved, maintaining towards LA

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Goddammit Lawrence, from whom do you take your orders?

dialogues.speaker: RECITER
dialogues.text: From Lord Feisal, in Feisal's tent.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Old fool! Why turn from him (Brighton) to him? (Lawrence) They are master and 7 man. an attitude of polite attention, LAWRENCE knows he is cro Rubicon.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: My lord... I think ... I think your Book is right. (he points to the Koran. FEISAL cocks his head enquiringly) "The desert is an ocean in which no oar is dipped". And on this ocean the Bedu go where they please and strike where they please ... This is the way the Bedu has always fought ... You are famed throughout the world for fighting in this way. And this is the way you should fight now. ALI agrees with every word of this and is rendered trebly BRIGHTON can barely comprehend such atrocious insubordina

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 49 163 Continued

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (disgusted, as one who gives up) Well I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (distressed) I'm sorry sir - but you're wrong! ; (he turns to FEISAL) i Fall back on Yenbo sir and the Arab Rising becomes one poor unit in the i British Army.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (wild with jealousy and suspicion) What is this to you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Lawrence, do you know that you're a traitor?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: No no ~ he is a young man, Colonel, and young men are passionate. They must say their say; but wiser people must decide. I know you are right. i

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (curtly) ; Very well, sir, when shall we move? The sooner the better sir, you'll lose another fifty men tonight.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (stung) You tread heavily ... But you speak the truth. I will give you my answer tomorrow. And now (he rises) it is late. en It is the dismissal. Allrise. BRIGHTON salutes. ALI salaa BRIGHTON politely ushers ALI out before himself, but hims precedes LAWRENCE. Just as LAWRENCE is following, FEISAL makes him a discreet signal to remain. Outside in the dar BRIGHTON and ALI regard the tent flap, expecting LAWRENCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 163 Continued It dawns on them that he has been detained for a private They stare at one another. They turn, and make their sepa ways between the tents. Inside the tent FEISAL and LAWRENCE both stand.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Colonel Brighton means to put my men under European Officers does he not?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: In effect my lord, yes.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: And I must do it, for the Turks have European guns. But I fear to do it upon my soulldo. The English have a great: hunger for desolate places, Lieutenant I _fear they hunger for Arabia.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Then you must deny it to them.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: You are an Englishman. Are you not loyal to England?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (hesitates, smiles a smile of intellectual, not emotive humour) To England and to other things. But FEISAL will not play the intellectual game, though am intellectual- for him the question is practical, and his serious as he draws up to LAWRENCE and says thoughifully:

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: To England and Arabia both? Andis that possible ...? (he approaches LAWRENCE closely and considers him. He nods) I think you are another of these desert- loving Englishmen - (he walks away) Doughty, Stanhope, Gordon of Khartoum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 163 Continued He indicates graciously the tent flap. They move over to 51 FEISAL (Cont) (he turns) No Arab loves the desert. We love water and green trees. There is nothing in the desert. Andno man needs nothing. (His tone changes from the philosophic to the emotional) ... or is it that you think we are something you can play with because we are a little people, a silly people; greedy, barbarous and cruel? (LAWRENCE looks surprised) But you know, Lieutenant, in the Arab city of Cordova were two miles of public lighting in the streets - when London was a village!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes, you were great.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (dryly) Nine centuries ago.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (mildly) Time to be great again my Lord.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (stiffly) Which is why my father made this war upon the Turks - my father, Mr. Lawrence, not the English! (he is suddenly overcome by melancholy) But my father is old andI - I long for the vanished Gardens of Cordova... (sighs) However, before the gardens must come the fighting. FEISAL courteously holds it apart.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (with formal politeness,smiling) To be great again, it seems we need the English or... (he shrugs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 52 163 Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (gently) Or ...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking out over the silence encampment) What no man can provide, Lieutenant. We need a miracle. FEISAL nods a polite goodnight, and LAWRENCE leaves. 164 CLOSE SHOT. Outside, LAWRENCE comes to a slow halt a yards from the tent. As he stands looking down at the gro deep thought, a slow dynamo-like theme begins on the SOUN An irritation crosses his mind, the music stops, and he l 165 MED. SHOT. BRIGHTON's brightly lit army tent glowing among its neighbours. 166 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE's eyes return to the ground and music begins again, then, very slowly, he walks off in th direction. 167 MED. SHOT. FEISAL is sitting alone inside his tent. H towards the tent flap trying to collect his curiously con about the young man outside. 168 CLOSE SHOT. A set of moonlit footprints in clean sand dynamo theme takes on an overtone of mysticism as the CAM pans upwards following the footprints, and we see the dar of LAWRENCE's back as he strolls slowly in deep thought t the open desert. 169 LONG SHOT. Two small FIGURES scamper along a sandy ri On reaching the end of a promontory, they stop. 170 CLOSE UP. FARRAJ and DAUD squat into picture, looking downwards with curiosity. 171 LONG SHOT. The small figure of LAWRENCE walking in th below. He comes to a stop with his hands in his pockets. 172 CLOSE UP. The two IMPS look down, puzzled. 173 LONG SHOT. The dark figure of LAWRENCE, standing in d concentration, outlinedagainst the brilliant white of the

dialogues.text: 173 174 175 176 17 178 179 180 53 Continued desert. The dynamic theme increases in intensity, and LAW begins to wander off in another direction.

dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT: A dawn sky. LAWRENCE is standing quite still oblivious of the two BOYS who squat down only a few yards CLOSE UP: The IMPS sit patiently watching LAWRENCE like t dogs watching their master. Then DAUD picks up a jagged s some bright colour and suggests in pantomime that he thro towards LAWRENCE. FARRAJ shakes his head, but unable to restrain himself, DAUD gently lobs it out of picture. MEDIUM SHOT: The stone lands at LAWRENCE's feet. At first seems not to notice it, but then, without interrupting hi tion, he aimlessly picks up the stone, bounces it up and palm of his hand, and walks slowly away. The IMPS get up out of picture.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: LONG SHOT: DAY. LAWRENCE is sitting under a stunted deser tree. One of the BOYS sits before him, the OTHER is busy him. Apart from this tiny group, the frame is completely above, below, and to either side. MEDIUM SHOT: The SAME. FARRAJ is hanging an odd piece of cloth in the branches so that LAWRENCE's head is shaded. four yards in front of LAWRENCE, with his back to camera, DAUD - also cross-legged - watching him as he continues p the stone. FARRAJ comes and sits down near to DAUD, so th LAWRENCE is framed between the backs of the two BOYS. The CAMERA starts. to creep in towards LAWRENCE. The music, which has never stopped, builds up andup. LAWRENCE begins hold the stone so tightly that his fist vibrates with the effort. He looks directly up at the two BOYS, but his eye focused on the distance and he is not really seeing them. CLOSE UP: The IMPS stare back. They don't know why, but t are rather frightened. CLOSE UP:. LAWRENCE. The music stops. There is a pause.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quietly) Akaba.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 181 CLOSE UP; The two BOYS don't understand. 182-MEDIUM SHOT: LAWRENCE and the BOYS. 183

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Akaba - from the land! 54 He comes to and chucks the stone at the BOYS. DAUD catche then looks up in surprise and points to LAWRENCE's hand, It is bleeding. LAWRENCE licks his palm mechanically, and above hand we see his gaze is no- longer inwards but outwards a excited. He gets to his feet. Exciting, whirling music be CAMERA PANS and TRACKS with LAWRENCE as he walks away from the three. The two BOYS follow close behind.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: walks faster and faster until he is running - as a man ru a specific destination. The music builds. The camp background and the run becomes a race. LAWRENCE appears in the disappears among the tents, and the BOYS put on a spurt but DAUD tri root and goes sprawling, and MUSIC stops when:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are mad. To come to Akaba by land we should have to cross the Nefud.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: ALIA
dialogues.text: The Nefud cannot be crossed.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'll cross it if you will.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (surprised) You? It takes more than a compass, Englishman. (LAWRENCE does not flicker) The Nefud is the worst place God created!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Oh I can't answer for the place. Only for myself. ALI begins to be fascinated. LAWRENCE drives on:  O 184 Continued eo

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Fifty men?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Fifty, against Akaba?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: If fifty men came out of the Nefud, they would be fifty men that other men might join. (lightly) The Howeitat are there I hear.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (promptly) The Howeitat are brigands; they will sell themselves to anyone.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Good fighters: though.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Good, yes... (bursts out) There are guns at Akaba.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: They face the sea Ali. And they cannot be turned round. From the landward side there are no guns at Akaha.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: With good reason! It cannot be approached from the landward side?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Certainly the Turks do not dream of it. He turns and points to the horizon. 185 LONG SHOT of this while he says on SOUND TRACK.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Akaba's over there Ali. It's only a matter of going. . 55  56

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (with horror and unwilling respect) You are mad!

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: 187 A ROCKY OUTCROP. Grey dawn. LAWRENCE burdened with pistol, bandolier and saddlebags is striding round the ed In the background, at a distance, is the camp with smoke ascending from one or two early fires, but no other sign Except, that is, when LAWRENCE looks over his shoulder to sure he has been been seen, and: 188 LONG SHOT. DAUD and FARRAJ are following. 189 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE does not look at all pleased or charmed, but he accepts the phenomenom as a sensible man accepts flies, that is without pleasure but also without skirting the curve of the outcrop he sees: 190 LONGSHOT. The RAIDING PARTY making its last minute preparations. Some of the camels are being loaded, some a already rearing to go; the atmosphere is as tense and tec as in a Grand Prix racing pit, except that there is no sh the contrary all is done very quietly. LAWRENCE pauses to in the scene and FEISAL steps out of the shelter of the r

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (smiles, but rather faintly and searchingly) And where are you going, Lieutenant - with fifty of my men?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (smiling ) To work your miracle.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Blasphemy. (he walks LAWRENCE into and through the RAIDING PARTY, knowing where LAWRENCE's camel is, CAMERA tracking) is a bad beginning to such a journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i 57 190 Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Ali did. Why not you?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (it is a bit awkward. He shifts his bags from one hand to the other) You are falling back, on Yenbo, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (glances at him side- long, muttering) Yes, yes, I must .... But I will spare these to you. They have arrived at LAWRENCE's camel; ALI is by it, busy his own. He looks at LAWRENCE but makes no greeting, defe aggressive.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Did Ali break confidence, to tell me? Before LAWRENCE can answer FEISAL holds up a hand and lis Quietness falls all about. The distant Muezzin is heard f camp and with a single wave-like rustling, all but LAWREN kneeling towards Mecca. He looks about; we see what he se then he busies himself quietly with his bags. When the pr ended ALI is the first to rise, and again he and LAWRENCE exchange their defensive-aggressive stare. FEISAL rises l

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Sherif Ali owes you his allegiance, my lord. (he gets into the saddle)

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (searchingly) Yet you did not tell Colonel Brighton.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (inexpressively) No. (he gets into the saddle)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 58 191 LONG SHOT. DAUD and FARRAJ hang off the RAIDING PARTY wistfully. 192 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE looks down into the CAMERA from camel, which has risen, and behind we see ALI and OTHERS similarly risen.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (smiling) Since you do know; we can claim to ride in the name of Feisal of Mecca.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (looking upwards, from LAWRENCE's angle) Yes, Lieutenant Lawrence, you may claim it. But in whose name do you ride? 194 CUT SHARPLY, with MUSIC quite loud, to the head and s of LAWRENCE, riding; broad day. His expression is that of excited young man who nevertheless controls himself. As h he slightly turns his head from left to right, trying to behind him without overtly turning round. The MUSIC gathe yet more force. Finally he is unable to overcome the temp twists right round in the saddle. 195 MED. SHOT. What he sees: (And with a crash the theme full pitch) The RAIDING PARTY strung out four abreast beh 196 CLOSE UP TRACKING. ALI and LAWRENCE. LAWRENCE turns to the front again, his eyes blazing. He straightens hims saddle and erects his head. His face is stiffened with di ecstasy. ALI has been watching him: he smiles sardonicall 197 CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. The CAMERA now starts to move do the line of RIDERS, introducing each in turn as they pass the shot trotting a little faster than the CAMERA. First ALI's two NEGRO SLAVES, magnificent in their red-tipped c Then banners, followed by exotic faces, fiercely and seri centrated ahead. Last of all come the baggage camels, lad food and rolled-up tents. We see, individually, GASIM, a cheerful, undersized and impoverished Bedouin, the ELDER a middle-aged and well-equipped warrior with a calm stron and MAJID a willowy young Ageyli with splendid clothes, m eyes and an elegant manner, but a dashing rider and most armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 198 LONG SHOT TRACKING. For the first time we see the RAI PARTY as awhole. The CAMERA follows it for quite some tim as it weaves its way through the multi-coloured sands and ALI raises his camel stick pointing out a change of direc from CAMERA. The MUSIC grows fainter and fainter as the RAIDERS draw away leaving a cloud of dust behind them. 199 MED. SHOT. Round the corner of a hillock we have just single and rather mangy camel appears with two RIDERS. As animal is brought to a halt we recognise FARRAJ and DAUD. is in front with FARRAJ mounted pillion-fashion behind hi hands clasped around DAUD's waist. The two IMPS furtively the desert ahead. 200 LONG SHOT. From their viewpoint we see the receding c of dust sent up by the RAIDING PARTY. . , 201 CLOSE SHOT. DAUD and FARRAJ. dialogues.speaker: GASIM
dialogues.text: I caught them Sherif. They have tracked us. They were here. (with an ingratiating nod to LAWRENCE) I caught them. ALI picks up his camel whip.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Why are you here? Boy. He pushes FARRAJ with his foot.

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: To serve Lord Aurens, Sherif. DAUD, having improved the moment by surreptitiously snatc handful of water, nods cheerfully at LAWRENCE. ALI looks LAWRENCE sardonically. LAWRENCE is attracted to the boys senses that the situation holds trouble for him.. He will part of them, and looks away as one bored or one who will concern in something no concern of his.. 1

dialogues.speaker: GASIM
dialogues.text: (anxious to be indispensable) That is true, Aurens. They do wish it. He turns for confirmation to the others, but LAWRENCE aga away, unconcerned, and doesn't even seem to hear what fol

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: You have been tracking us. (he looks uneasily over the horizon. He twitches his whip) You were told to stay!

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: No Sherif, our camel strayed. We followed her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: co © 61 207 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DAUD
dialogues.text: (solemnly) She led us here to be Lord Auren's servants. (looking at LAWRENCE) : It is the will of Allah.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (technically, not angrily) Blasphemy. He brings the whip down hard on DAUD's shoillders. At onc LAWRENCE looks up.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Don't do that. Immediate silence. He rises. He is hesitating. GASIM step save him from a social blunder.

dialogues.speaker: GASIM
dialogues.text: Oh these are not servants Aurens - these : are... outcasts, parentless ... . (he shrugs, not expressing ‘pity but on the contrary apologising for such creatures)

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: _ (shortly) ' Be warned. They are not suitable. ,

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: They sound very suitable ... You.can ride with the baggage. They are at his feet, touching head and heart. ALI stalks disgustedly, turning only to say:

dialogues.speaker: ALI

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: All right. With a nod and rather awkward smile, he moves away. GASIM after him and calls (if possible from an empty uncluttere that he has "significance".).

dialogues.text: They will be lucky for you! (with the dreadful piety of a thorough-going sinner:) Allah favours the compassionate! cuT 210-The singing wires of the telegraph above the railway.

dialogues.text: From now on we must travel by night. And rest while it is too hot to travel. A few hours each day. (he watches the effect of this)

dialogues.text: (concentrating on his shaving) Mmm. Why don't we start now?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: No, no. (sweetly) We still rest now; three hours.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (goes on shaving) Fine. I'll wake you.

dialogues.text: (even he cannot hide entirely his relief. He shrugs.) God willing.

dialogues.speaker: ALI

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (his voice and manner crammed with occidental impatience and contempt) Nothing is “written. He bursts between them. ALI goes alongside, not attemptin longer to detain hity, but incoherent with venom. “ ALI , Go back! English! Blasphemer! What then --- what? What did you bring us here for --- with your blasphemous conceit? Eh --- English blasphemer? Akaba? Was it Akaba? You will not be at Akaba, English! Go back, blasphemer, but you will not be at Akaba! This absolate loss of control yelled into LAWRENCE's face him the most exquisite satisfaction --- It is victory. To point home, he turns his most amused, most donnish expres upon his hated friend and says pleasantly:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I shall be at Akaba. That is written. (points to his own head) In here. (he smiles with deliberate mildness) ALI stops and looks after him trembling; he casts about f word he can think of.
