We see LAWRENCE and DAUD's camels below as FARRAJ falls over himself, his water bottle flying. CLOSE SHOT. ALI. In the background the RAIDERS rise to th feet and start walking towards the desert. ALI's face is ulous, hopeful, and a little apprehensive. MED. SHOT. DAUD and LAWRENCE, with GASIM mounted behind him, coming in off the desert. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. FARRAJ running, yelling across the desert. CLOSE UP. DAUD. Recognising his companion he starts yelli too, and stirs his camel forward. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. ALI. Surrounded by hurrying men he reaches the sand. CLOSE UP, LAWRENCE looking out ahead. LONG SHOT. The two GROUPS converge with FARRAJ the first to make contact. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. FARRAJ and DAUD. FARRAJ holds up the watter bottle.

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: Daud. Daud. DAUD smiles down wearily. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. ALI. After a few steps he comes to a standstill. MED, SHOT. The two camels, surrounded by the RAIDING PART They come to a halt and the camels kneel to the ground. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE and GASIM. MEN pull the exhausted GASIM from the camel. LAWRENCE remains slumped in the sad He looks towards ALI. CLOSE SHOT. ALI. He walks forward with a half smile that happy defeat. CLOSE SHOT. FARRAJ and DAUD embracing. i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 342 343/6 11 CLOSE SHOT, ALI walks into picture beside LAWRENCE and ha him a bottle. LAWRENCE is about to drink, but he takes th from his lips and raises his heal.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (he croaks) ~ Nothing is written. As he drinks we hear a shocked, amused, admiring, murmur: Aurens, Aurens, Aurens. He slithers from the saddle and places his feet gingerly He looks about. MED. SHOT. Several of the RAIDERS have spread their saddl cloths on the ground. Now he is eagerly invited by two or to confer the honour upon them.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER HARITH
dialogues.text: (smiling) Aurens!

dialogues.speaker: MAJID
dialogues.text: (smiling) Aurens! LAWRENCE smiles and goes over to the nearest. He looks at It calls. But he painfully takes off his shirt and calls, looking, as though for help.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Farraj! FARRAJ comes.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (giving him the shirt) Wash. Then he looks down at the brightly patterned saddlecloth light going out he releases the body from the mind's cont almost collapses into sleep. (It must not be a faint thou Instantly, FARRAJ begins to unlace his boots, and a shado thrown over LAWRENCE asa cloth shelter is erected over hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © 18 CLOSE SHOT, LAWRENCE, His eyes have opened and gleam in the light.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: F os softly) arraj! FARRAJ comes with a prepared dish of food, which he lays LAWRENCE. LAWRENCE raises himself on one elbow, considers ” it and begins to spoon it carefully into his mouth, wat a

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (quietly) El Aurens... Truly, for some men nothing is written unless they write it. (it is capitulation)

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (moved, he laughs quietly, goes on eating. Then:) Not 'El Aurens', Just Lawrence.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: El Aurens is better.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: True.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Your father too: Just Mr. Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (considers this. Pushes away the food. Turns on his back and closes his eyes as though asleep, and says with an effort) My father is Sir Thomas Chapman.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (pleased) Is that a Lord?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: A kind of a Lord.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Then when he dies you too will be a Lord,  ts 347 Continued 79

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (sympathetic) Ah. You have an elder brother. (a common complaint among aristocrats like himself)

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: But then... (another point strikes him) I do not understand this - Your father's name is Chapman -

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Ali. My father isn't really my father. He didn't marry my mother. (the words ‘father’ and 'mother' come out on a barely perceptible’ effort of breath)

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (gravely) I see. (he is disturbed. He must think this out. Silence.)

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. . (and this is not bitter but a humble though dignified apology for a fault.)

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (after further thought; quietly) It seems to me that you are free to choose your own name then.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (he keeps his eyes tightly shut) Yes, I suppose I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 347 348 349 80 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALI _
dialogues.text: (with a quick smile ~ and this is an act of real moral generosity) "El Aurens" is best.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: “(after a pause in which he con- trols the surge of gratitude - dangerously similar to love - which rises in him) All right, I'll settle for "El Aurens." He feigns sleep. ALI covers him and goes over to the fire DAUD and FARRAJ are there, now asleep. By FARRAJ are neat piled LAWRENCE's shirt, shorts, socks, with the webbing b top.. ALI takes them up. FARRAJ wakes. ALI throws the clo one by one on the fire. FARRAJ looks from them to him wit mouth open in horrified enquiry. CLOSE SHOT. BROAD DAY. . LAWRENCE, hand on dagger in Arab robes. MED, SHOT. ALI, ELDER HARITH, MAJID, and others regard hi

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: They are the robes of a Sherif of the Beni Wejh.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (stroking the silk) Very fine. (he turns a circle, smiles, awkward with pleasure and emotion) Great honour.

dialogues.speaker: MAJID
dialogues.text: (courteous) The honour is tous. Salaams Sherif,

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ AND DAUD
dialogues.text: (delighted) Salaams Sherif.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (to ALI) It is permitted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘O Nd 349 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Surely.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER HARITH
dialogues.text: ce) He for whoni nothing is written may write ' himself aclan. Salaam. ' ‘ : LAWRENCE Salaams. ‘ He strides a hestitant pace or two and smiles bashfully.. it is he who is waiting for a lead.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER HARITH
dialogues.text: ‘ (tactfully boisterous) © . They are good for riding. Try!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (eagerly) a Yes. eo (he turns and picks up his camel saddle, turns back to them. ' Strongly.) , Great honour! As he goes we hear the murmur rise to a shout: 'Aurens!"

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: 350 CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. LAWRENCE (head and shoulders) ri MUSIC. 351 REVERSE LONG SHOT, LAWRENCE galloping towards CAMERA. The RAIDERS, distant, are watching. When he approaches CAMERA, LAWRENCE reins in and turns to look at the RAIDER Cc 352 MED. SHOT.. The RAIDERS raise their hands. 353 MED. SHOT. LAWRENCE raises his hand to them and urges camel off at a right angle. CAMERA (situated as in REVERS LONG SHOT above) PANS with this and the RAIDERS are cut o oO from view by the bank of the Wadi, which LAWRENCE is e { When the RAIDERS are quite cut off from view: | © 354 CLOSE SHOT. He dismounts. He stands erect; his fa but his eyes are smiling, like a man listening to music.
jo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 82 MED, TRACKING SHOT. He walks a swinging pace or two. He draws his dagger and with an expression of extreme nobili threatens with it -- who? Himself perhaps. His eyes fall upon the dagger as though it were someone else who held i his face relaxes in self-mockery, though he does not exac In any case he is for the moment happy enough to tolerate He slams the dagger into its sheath and sets off briskly. suddenly, causing the robes to fly. And so on, the music Though the actions are histrionic his expression is manly almost cautious, and we can see that this is more than pl As he goes, striding, stopping and turning, with slow gra of the arms, CAMERA FOLLOWS closely. LONG SHOT. Angling down. He sets off with a swinging stri particular direction. CAMERA PANNING slightly, but he is progressing diagonally across the screen. A MAN on a STAT HORSE thus enters the opposite corner of the screen, unse . LAWRENCE until they are almost nose to nose. MED. SHOT. THEY regard one another. CLOSE SHOT. The manis AUDA. The complete desert Bedouin. His face is haggard, fierce, dignified and childish. His are raised in amused enquiry. MUSIC stops.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: What are you doing -- Englishman?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: {with equal insouciance -- hands on hips) As you see. . (glances round the rim of the basin, carelessly) Are you alone?

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Almost. Are you with that party of dogs who are drinking at my well?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (stiffens with immediate interest) Yours?. : AUDA takes out his pistol and fires a single shot in the thrusting it back into his belt.  Cc” 358 voy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 83 Continued

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: 1am Auda Ibu Tayi. (he expects this to have an effect)

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (as one who notes a mild coin- cidence) Ah. Ihave heard of another man of that name.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Other? (roaring) What other?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: The Auda I heard of would not need to , summon help -- (indicating the pistol) to look after his wells.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Ah. He must be a great hero.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: He is. He would not refuse water to men coming out of the Great Nefudh desert.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Would he not? Truly that must be some other man. (he jerks his head) Here is my "help". An impressive and dignified BOY of about ten years, on a Arab pony tears down the side of the dune and joins them. LAWRENCE exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (leans down from his horse and flicks LAWRENCE's garments with his whip) Son, what fashion is this?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: Harith, father. :

dialogues.speaker: 362D
dialogues.text: 84 Continued

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: And “what manner of Harith?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: A Beni Wejh Sherif, father.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: And is he Harith?

dialogues.speaker: BOY
dialogues.text: No father. English. AUDA nods sardonically and wheels his horse to go.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Son, they are stealing our water. Tell them we are coming. The BOY drags out an enormous pistol and holds it upwards AUDA inquiringly, his eyes sparkling.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Yes! Tell them! CLOSE SHOT. The BOY fires. The two bound out of frame. MED. SHOT. From LAWRENCE's point of view, they tear away the end of the Wadi and wheel, in a spurt of sand, toward so disappearing from view. As they go, their passage brin LAWRENCE's camel uneasily to its feet, where it stands he MED. SHOT. LAWRENCE races through the sand towards it. LONG SHOT ... AUDA and SON arrive ... snatch water bottle

dialogues.speaker: GASIM
dialogues.text: MED. SHOT ... AUDA with water bottle moving forward from

dialogues.speaker: OR
dialogues.text: AUDA still - holding the bottle up. REACTION SHOT ... RAIDING PARTY. CLOSE SHOT ... AUDA empties bottle and throws it left.

dialogues.speaker: 369A
dialogues.text: 370 371 “372 373 85 MEDIUM SHOT. AUDA throws bottle at GASIM's feet and circl intercut may be with AUDA's SON watching. LAWRENCE gallops up to beside AUDA's SON. AUDA's SON pulls gun. DAUD and FARRAJ reacting. LAWRENCE hand raised - he smiles. - AUDA'SSON ... smiles - cocks, gun and loses smile AUDA as well - dialogue "You empty that' ALI steps in f.g. ‘do not' (not yet shot) AUDA: ‘It is Auda of the Howeitat who spea ALI 'It is Ali of the Harith who answers' ... moves forwa AUDA ‘sizes up ALI (to be shot) and moves forward. AUDA and ALI meet in TWO SHOT and continue as script

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (as one who makes an effort of memory, politely to recollect an obscure name, thoughtfully) Harith ... Ali (his face clears; with exaggerated ; delicacy) Does your father still steal?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Auda! (sharply) uda, (AUDA turns) CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE from AUDA's viewpoint.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: We are fifty; you are two. How if we shot you down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 86 373 Continued.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Why then you have a blood feud with the Howeitat. Do you desire it?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (smiles and bows his head) Not the Generals in Cairo nor the Sultan, himself desire that. (he smiles, indicating the BOY) Call off your men. 374 WIDER ANGLE MED, SHOT LAWRENCE, AUDA, the BOY, ALI.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (testily, and as one who repeats a lesson to a backward pupil) No, no, boy -- this honours the unworthy. (the BOY holsters the gun, and as LAWRENCE rides up to him he continues, mock-apologetic) Ihave only just begun to teach him.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (serious and with a trace of disesteem) And what is it you're teaching him today? {he indicates the scattered men and vessels) Howeitat hospitality?

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (he is caught; his face darkens and he growls) Be not clever with me, English ... (he says to ALI shortly and as though LAWRENCE were not present) Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quickly) A friend of Prince Feisal's.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (looks at him and ALI with some interest, cautiously) So.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ron 374 a 315 87 Continued AUDA (cont) (to ALI) . And you desire my hospitality?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quickly and looking warningly and compellingly at ALI) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (to ALI) Is he your tongue?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (shortly) We do desire it.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Then it is given. (deprecating) If you will take it -- Iam at my summer camp, a poor place. (as one wishing to be even pedantically correct) To me it seems a poor place, some men find ifmarvellous. Tomorrow maybe I will allow the Turks to buy you, friends of Feisal. But dine with me. (as soon as he has said this magic phrase his pride becomes straightforward) Yes, Dine with Auda, English. Dine with the Howeitat, Harith. It is my pleasure that you dine with me -- in Wadi Rhumm!

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: LONG SHOF.. Angling down. WADRIRHUMM. This scene is epi in scale, Biblical inform. The floor of the Wadi is benea its walls tower above us. AUDA's camp comprises some hund black tents, one of particular magnificence having a clea it. There are pools of water with small trees giving shad black sheep, a herd of horses. Smoke ascends from scores fires at which the women work, though here and there a wo her way between the tents on an ass, followed by her chil two groups of men are mounted on trotting horses, but mos horses are tethered and the general effect is of leisure, mildest sort of activity. The CAMERA PANS over this scene  a

LONG SHOT. THE CAMP. The echo of a shot bounds back and f between the cliffs. There is one second of inactivity, an and children appear from almost all of the tents, looking them. Men appear similarly and run to their horses. MED. SHOT. AUDA, ALI, LAWRENCE. AUDA looks down as before he is no longer concerned to show off even slightly. He i of what he sees and also alert to see that it is done cor another shot, and leads the way forward and down. LONG SHOT, THE CAMP, from the floor of the Wadi. The-echo AUDA's second shot still flying; more and more mounted me making in one direction; women snatching children away fr horses into the shelter of the tents. MED, SHOT. By the big tent AUDA's standard. A flying hors plucks it from the ground. On SOUND TRACK a gathering noi MED, TRACKING SHOT. THE RAIDERS, MAJID with the banner prominent in the background. AUDA smiles. LONG SHOT. What he sees. We are approaching the tents, fr which AUDA's HORSEMEN are speeding to meet us, joy-shooti MED. SHOT. CAMERA PANS along the RAIDERS. They look defia Backs are straightened. Their dusty, crumpled, sometimes garments rearranged. They pack more closely together as t of the horsemen arrive. LONG SHOT. THE RAIDERS, surrounded by the HORSEMEN who circle about them, shouting AUDA's name and firing into t MED. TRACKING SHOT. AUDA, LAWRENCE, and ALI. MED. SHOT. From their viewpoint; CAMERA PANS swiftly with a group of encircling HOWEITAT. MED. TRACKING SHOT. ELDER HARITH, MAJID, and other RAIDER face ahead but look convertly sideways. MED, SHOT. AUDA spursa little ahead. MED. SHOT. From his viewpoint. The whirling wall of horse breaks before him, wheeling away (not too neatly; it is n disclose the tents. Shooting stops. MED. TRACKING SHOT. The RAIDERS ride between the tents. T is now no noise and the HOWEITAT have formed themselves i and threatening escort, riding alongside. Their clothes are good, in some cases splendid; their wea their mounts fresh and well-groomed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 390 391 392 393 394 395 396 397 398 399 400 89 CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. MAJID. He turns his head and looks balefully at: CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. HOWEITAT STANDARD BEARER. He returns the look. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. GASIM.. The HOWEITAT are now crowding the RAIDERS; he is nervous but does his best. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. A splendid HOWEITAT eyes him up and down. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. ELDER HARITH, being crowded. Without looking, he crowds back. MED. TRACKING SHOT. From the RAIDERS' viewpoint, the moving sea of HOWEITAT look towards us, poker-faced among the tenis. : MED. TRACKING SHOT. From behind, we PAN over the heads of the HOWEITAT along the camel-borne RAIDERS, ending on the leaders. The whole cavalcade comes to a stop, except for ALI and LAWRENCE who ride on, watched by the others, into clear space. MED. TRACKING SHOT. These THREE ride towards us, others i the background. AUDA dismounts. He salutes his guests, an gestures,

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Auda's tent. CLOSE SHOT. AUDA'S TENT. It is a woven palace. MED. SHOT. Ata signal from the ELDER HARITH, the camels of the RAIDERS sink down to their knees among the horseme seeming to be swallowed up.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: INSIDE AUDA'S TENT. NIGHT. It is brilliantly lit within. night without is ringed with fires. The remains of a sple is before them. Slaves attend with coffee. AUDA reclines and belches politely. He is satiated but his little eyes alive. He has much on his mind,

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (reflectively) This thing you work against Akaba. What profit do you hope from it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 Continued

dialogues.speaker: . ALI
dialogues.text: We work it for Feisal of Mecca. The Harith do not work for profit. (unlike some he could mention)

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (unruffled) Well, if it is in a man to be a servant, Sherif Ali, he could find worse masters than Feisal. But I -- I cannot ‘serve.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quietly) You permit the Turks to stay in Akaba.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (short) Yes. It is my pleasure. LAWRENCE leans forward and takes a morsel from the plate. Carefully.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: We do not work this thing for Feisal...

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (insolently, to ALI) No? For the English then?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quick) For the Arabs.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: The Arabs? ... The Howeitat, Ageyli, Rualla, Beni Sahkr, these I know - I have even heard of the Harith - but the "Arabs": what tribe is that? LAWRENCE laughs, AUDA looks pleased, but:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: They are a tribe: of slaves. And AUDA goes gray at the insult.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued 91

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: They serve the Turks.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (muttering) Well they are nothing to me. My tribe is the Howeitat!

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Who work only for profit.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Who work at Auda's pleasure!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: And Auda's pleasure is to serve the Turks.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (deeply dangerous, between . incredulity and rage) Serve? I, serve?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the servant who takes money. AUDA leaps to his feet and backs away from this moral thr another man might from a physical one.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Tam Auda Ibu Tayi! He goes to the edge of the tent and bawls into the darkne Does Auda ‘serve? Does Auda Ibu Tayi serve? He faces his persecutors and goes into a furious litany: I carry twenty-three great wounds all got in battle! Seventy-five men I have killed with my own hands, in battle! I scatter, I burn my enemies‘ tents! I take away their flocks and herds. The Turks pay me a golden treasure. Yet Iam poor! ... BecauseI ama river to my people! Is that service?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 7  92 O 400 Continued AUDA sees his admiration is genuine. He approaches. He si

dialogues.speaker: ' MAJID
dialogues.text: (sadly) ‘ 5S Yet now it seems Auda has grown old. ' And lost his taste for fighting.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: It is well you say it in my tent. Thou tulip. , ALI ’ Yet this is a tulip the Turks could not buy.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: o Why should they wish to? . (to LAWRENCE) Now I will tell you what they pay me. And you will tell me if this is a servant's wages. (impressive) They pay me, month by month... one hundred golden guineas. dL ALI, MAJID, and others are dumbfounded, but: ’

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: A hundred and fifty, Auda.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Who told thee that? on LAWRENCE t3 Thave long ears.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: And a long tongue between them. © LAWRENCE A hundred, a hundred and fifty, what matters? It is a trifle. (AUDA stares) A trifle. Which they take from a great box CS they have...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a ALI ¢ In Akaba.  Od Oo 400 Continued

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: , (glowers) : In Akaba? oO LAWRENCE ' Where else? ‘ AUDA You trouble me! Like women!

dialogues.speaker: 'S
dialogues.text: LAWRENCE laughs delightedly.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Friends, we have been foolish. oO will not come to Akaba...

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: No. oN LAWRENCE eM --- for Money ---

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: No. © LAWRENCE --- for Feisal ---

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: No. Me LAWRENCE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: then:) 93 Auda -- nor to drive the Turks away. He will come because it is his pleasure. (contemplates him, grimly, Thy mother mated with a scorpion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: y 401 LONG SHOT. EARLY MORNING. AUDA'S CAMP. The column ards and bodyguards at the rear. 402 MED. SHOT. AUDA mounts. °y is assembled in reverse order, i.e. with the leaders,  402 403 404 405 406 407 408 409 94 Continued

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Make God your agent! The leaders mount and move off between the ‘TRIBESMEN. LONG SHOT. As they advance, the TRIBESMEN cry:

dialogues.speaker: TRIBESMEN
dialogues.text: Auda Ibu Tayi!

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Peace be with you! LONG SHOT. As they move, they peel up their followers as country dance, behind them. A tremendous amount of ‘showi takes place in the matter of horsemanship. EXTREME LONG AERIAL SHOT. The HOWEITAT,, ant-like, crawl away from the cliffs of Rhumm across a limitless la

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXTREME LONG SHOT. RIGHT. We look across fold after fold of lunar mountains, to where the lights of a town twinkle sea. In foreground LAWRENCE and ALI look towards this. AL looks to LAWRENCE, smiles at his expression and says:

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Yes. Akaba... CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE rolls over happily and slithers down the slope a little. He looks down contentedly at: MED. LONG SHOT. P.O.V. LAWRENCE. In the wadi below, the column. There are no fires or shelters, but the beasts ga in clumps and the men mostly lie or sit, in groups. The l mur of their voices ascends. CLOSE SHOT. ALI slithers down to join LAWRENCE.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Tomorrow we will go and get it.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (soberly) D’you think we shall?  Wwe

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Yes, if you are right about the guns. LAWRENCE opens his mouth to reply but from the Wadi a sin shot cannons out. He looks to ALI, but after a single spl ALI is gone from the frame with a celerity which indicate some specific, serious thing has happened. MED. LONG SHOT P.0.V. LAWRENCE. In the Wadi, the BEDOUIN are on their feet, converging on a point where there is a knot of men, and shouting. MED. TRACKING SHOT. ALI descending in a rush. Just as he is leaving the foot of the frame, LAWRENCE appears at the head of it, following more slowly. MED. SHOT. dialogues.text: Ali, get a message down the coast to Yenbo. Tell Feisal to find boats -- any boats -- and bring the Arab Army here to Akaba. Quickly.

dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY. He is seated at his desk in the offi previously occupied by MURRAY. Most of the furniture has changed together with pictures and other ornamentation. O wall behind him hangs a calendar depicting month by month bucolic England whichis no longer, and probably never was office now has an airy atmosphere with everything in appl order. ALLENBY is a footballer, burly and fit; a gentlema and self-respecting; a General Officer who has thoroughly lated power, shrewd, commanding, daring, and humble. He i reading with quiet concentration a personal dossier. His flat, with no trace of comment, as if it might be a shopp he is checking.

In the background we can s DRYDEN (nearest CAMERA) and BRIGHTON. ..- Several languages ... knowledge of music... literature... (he browses) The CAMERA comes.to rest on a CLOSE SHOT OF LAWRENCE, still in Arab clothes. He looks across the desk at ALLENB cautiously. On the otherwise vacant desk we see three pho graphs. These are a rubgy team, an English gentlewoman wi a discreet dependent face and a single link of pearls, an child on a New Forest pony in front of a country house. Knowledge of ... knowledge of ... CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY. He looks up and it is impossible to tell from his expression or his voice whether he is satir

dialogues.text: Who told you to take Akaba?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: --- Sir. He says this after a pause and rather quietly, without a personal indignation, not insisting on his own rights but indicating that the courtesies are to be observed. Tt sho concern not for his own privileges but as it were a fathe lest LAWRENCE should by his behaviour let himself down.

dialogues.text: are Sir. ALLENBY now turns sideways to LAWRENCE and commences a sort of forensic examination, his tone being light, quick dispassionate. Now the pace goes ding-dong between them.

dialogues.text: So?  ry os"

I led him into a quicksand ... the other was a man -- that was, oh let me see -- before Akaba anyway -- I had to execute him with my pistol ... there was something about it I didn't like.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (with no trace of comment in his tone) So you'll hold down the Turkish Desert Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (nowinfuses a shade of mockery) With a thousand Arabs? CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE. He commences with enthusiasm and ends fanatically, leaning forward almost as if it were ALLENBY threatening. ~

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: A thousand Arabs means a thousand knives; delivered anywhere, day or night. It means a thousand camels; that means a thousand packs.of high explosive and a thousand crack rifles. We can cross Arabia while Johnny Turk' s still turning round. I'll smash his - railways and while he's mending them I'll smash them somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAWRENCE (off) In thirteen weeks I can have Arabia in chaos! ALLENBY replies with deliberate mildness, as one clearing small point of information.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: You are going back then? MED SHOT: .LAWRENCE is given a moment's blank pause. Then he laughs, and runs over ALLENBY with equivocal self-mock charm.  652 Continued There is no 137

dialogues.text: Yes. Of course I'm going back.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Hm. If we can see it, so can the Turks. If he finds he's using four Divisions to fend off a handful of bandits, he'll withdraw.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: He daren't withdraw. Arabia's part of his Empire. If he gets out now he knows he'll never get back again:

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: I wonder who will...

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No-one will. Arabia's for the Arabs now. response. ALLENBY and DRYDEN drink. ILAWRENCE looks from one to the other. He throws a small piece of potato-crisp ‘into the fountai swim for it.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: That's what I told them anyway. That's what they think, and that's why they're fighting.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (deadpan in the silence) Oh surely. LAWRENCE looks down into his drink.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (slowly) They've only one suspicion; that we'll let them move the Turks out and then move in ourselves. I've told them that that's false, that we have no ambitions in Arabia. (suddenly he looks up-at ALLENBY -with great penetration) Have we?

dialogues.speaker: . ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (caught a little off-guard) I'm not a politician, thank God. Have we ambitions in Arabia Dryden? The fish

(to be grouped and arranged t recall as closely as possible the shot in which ALI prese robes surrounded by the smiling RAIDING PARTY). One or tw the OFFICERS essay a smile. Then, suddenly they come forward quickly, smiling and con As the CAMERA LIFTS AWAY, we see LAWRENCE begin patted on the back, congratulated, his hand shaken, a drink offered refused. He shrinks away from them as best he can, fendin with a smile which is so superficial, so withdrawn, so al ish as to be a repellent, not a real smile at all. They c about him and the music continues very loudly, until sudd MUSIC STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: GALLERY CORRIDOR
dialogues.text: CLOSE TRACKING SHOT: ALLENBY, DRYDEN and BRIGHTON. They are walking back along one of the silent corridors. they walk briskly and in step. Their steps echo and they look at one another.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Are you really going to give them artillery sir?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Iwas wondering that, sir. Might be deuced difficult to get it back again.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (softly) Give them artillery and you've made them independent.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Then I can't give them artillery can 1?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (deprecatingly) For you to say, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: No it's not. I've got orders to obey, thank God... Not like that poor devil! (jerking his head backwards) He''s riding the whirlwind.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: . (dryly) Let's hope we're not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 666 142 MED. SHOT Shooting on their backs as they enter picture a off into EXTREME LONG SHOT down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is sitting in the stern of a long boat, leaving in the small and rusty coastal steamer with one or two dilapidat about it. At his feet are a pair of leather travelling ba awkwardly to the motion of the beat (it is a rowing boat; oars) festooned with camera cases, dressed in a light sui hat, he is an incongruous, even absurdfigure. Buthe makes attempt to be less so. He has been in unlikelier situatio will again. Clutching the gunwhale with one hand he exami approaching shore steadily. His tough, alert and cynicall face is alive with curiosity. This shot lasts no longer t to take it in, whereupon:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Arab ROWERS skip from it and haul it up the beach a l BENTLEY superintends the landing of his scanty baggage. H attitude to the Arab is that of neither the sahib nor the but simply of a rather graceless man who wants his bags. cases are shouldered by TWO ARABS and he sets off after t the beach. MEDIUM LONG SHOT from behind BENTLEY and BEARERS, in

dialogues.speaker: FOREGROUND
dialogues.text: We see the seaward fringe of the village-town of Akaba am scruffy palm trees. The same dilapidated buildings as bef among them a few indolent MEN and donkeys and unoccupied CHILDREN. But coming down the beach in the contrary direc is a file of ragged STEVEDORES, bearing handsomely woven bags, inlaid boxes, and rolled carpets. BENTLEY'S BEARERS pause. At the end of the file comes SELIM (the RECITER). ceremony, Bentley's bags are dumped and his MEN rush to h quarrelsomely in the stowing of the camel bags, etc. in t BENTLEY is unruffled by the insult to himself, but sharpl He accosts SELIM, raising his hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, friend. Who do these bags belong to? SELIM looks at him gravely. Then:

dialogues.speaker: SELIM
dialogues.text: To Prince Feisal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: om

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: 3 8 Continued BENTLEY grunts. A thought strikes him. A knowing smile.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You're not Prince Feisal by any chance? SELIM is not shocked but is interested by such ample igno

dialogues.speaker: SELIM
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You know him though? (indicating the baggage)

dialogues.speaker: SELIM
dialogues.text: He is my master. Iam his servant. BENTLEY nods comprehendingly and lugs a business card fro pocket. In the act of offering it he pauses and with drea

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Can you read? SELIM flickers him a look of mild surprise. Then, having card, he beckons silently and starts away up the beach, B following. |

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost stripped of furnishings. In the foreground, FEISAL examining BENTLEY's card. In background, BODYGUARDS carry out some more camel bags. A SERVANT places a metal coffee set conveniently to hand by a window embrasure wit in it. FEISAL hands back the card. BENTLEY says, wagging card before putting it away.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: The "Chicago Courier" is my own particular paper, but my work is syndicated throughout America.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: I understood so from your letter. Iam glad we effected our meeting, Mr. Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5 co) Continued He gestures and they both sit in the embrasure. The windo looks the courtyard. FEISAL smiles: :

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Now ...?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Where can I find Major Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL ,
dialogues.text: (the smile going) Is that what you have come for?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (covering up) Not altogether sir, no...

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (dry) Well you will find Major Lawrence with my army Mr. Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: That's. what I meant sir. Where will I find your army?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: I don't know. BENTLEY stares. Last week they were near El Ghira.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (incredulous horror) Ghirat

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (smiling) Oh yes. I fear you have a long journey. Can you ride a camel? :

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: I've never tried.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Take a mule. If I were you I should try Buldulla. Avoid Malaal - the Turks are there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © . eo 4 Continued

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: In Malaal now? They move fast.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: They do. But not so fast as we do you will find. (he hesitates, then says:) Myself, Iam going to Cairo, as you know.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (looks up from his pad; he has caught the change of tone instantly) Yes.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: There is work for me there of a different kind.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Yes. FEISAL feels it is now BENTLEY's turn, and keeps silent. BENTLEY amplifies his last word. I understand that you've. been given no artillery.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: That is so.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You're handicapped.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (deprecatingly) It... restricts us to small things.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: It's intended to. There can be no mistaking this. FEISAL addresses him very directly:

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Do you know General Allenby?  4 Continued

dialogues.speaker: O
dialogues.text: ° BENTLEY Watch out for Allenby. A slim customer.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (inclines politely) fo) Excuse me? c / BENTLEY A clever man.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (the scholar for a moment) "Slim customer"; very good. (to BENTLEY) I shall certainly "watch out for" him. Cc (he considers, then says:) You are being very ... sympathetic, Mr. Bentley.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: a (with that curious sincere ° Oo insincerity of the news- . hawk on the job) | Your Highness, we Americans were once | a Colonial people. We naturally sympathize with any people anywhere who are struggling for their freedom. FEISAL doesn't even pretend to consider this as a serious

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LO) . Very gratifying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, a genuine im- pulsive laugh of sheer © amusement and appreciation) Also, my interests are the same as yours, sir. You want your story told. I badly want a story to tell. Cc FEISAL (is amused and approving in his turn) Ah. Now you are "talking turkey" are you not?

dialogues.speaker: VS
dialogues.text: Oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Continued And now they are both amused, and surprised to find how w are getting on together, each in his own way being a shre liking shrewdness in others. and walks about a little, cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Bentley, I will give youa guide. Anda letter. And before I leave here ... (he breaks off and consults a fine gold watch, pursing his lips) .«++ Ah which must be presently ... I will have some facts and figures put on paper for you. You will find that we have done many things, small but many. You know of course that we are destroying the Turkish railways ...

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (head bent, scribbling) Yes, sir. Major Lawrence is in charge of all this is he?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (pauses and looks at the bent head with some coldness) My army is made up of Tribes. The Tribes are led by the Tribal leaders.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (looks up; insistently) Your people do think very highly of Major Lawrence though?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (sharply) (he goes to the window and looks out) And rightly. In this country, Mr. Bentley, Yes. the man who gives victory in battle is prized .. (sadly) beyond every other man... (he is silent for a moment and then murmurs, mindless of the repetition) FEISAL rises swiftly from his chair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 4 Continued BENTLEY is scribbling this down but does a horrified doub FEISAL (Cont) Myself Iam going to Cairo... (abstractedly he returns and sits, facing BENTLEY. His eye lights upon the pad and this draws his attention back from his own thoughts) One figure I can give you from my head; because it never leaves my head. Since starting this campaign four months ago we have lost thirty-seven wounded, one hundred and fifty-six dead. You remark the disproportion between our dead and wounded.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (wondering, even awed) Yes; four times as many.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: That is because those too badly wounded to bring away, we ourselveskill. We leave no wounded for the Turks.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (gently) You mean ...?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: I mean we leave no wounded for the Turks. (more moderately) In their eyes we are not soldiers but rebels. And rebels, wounded or whole are not protected by the Geneva Code, and are treated ++. harshly.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: How harshly?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: More harshly than i ‘hope you can imagine.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: I see.  4 Continued -8

dialogues.speaker: , FEISAL
dialogues.text: Our own prisoners, Mr. Bentley, are taken care of, until the British can relieve \ us of them, according tothe Code. I should like you to notice that.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (scribbling) Ido, sir. (off-hand again) Is that the influence of Major Lawrence? This time FEISAL's eyes snap with a direct anger and jeal

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Why should you suppose so?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (a bit thrown at thus receiving for the first time the full impact of Royal personality) Welll... it's just ... I heard in Cairo, that the Major has a... horror of bloodshed.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL -
dialogues.text: That is exactly so. With Major Lawrence, mercy is a passion. With me it is merely good manners. You may judge which motive is the more reliable. (he half pulls out the watch again) And now perhaps ...

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY ,
dialogues.text: (rising immediately) i Sure. Thank you, sir. (he moves away towards the door) D'you think you'll be able to manage the letter and...

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (quiet reproof) I will do everything that I have said, Mr. Bentley. BENTLEY, a bit rebuffed, nods smiling and goes to the doo where he is arrested by:  oO ¢

dialogues.speaker: Q
dialogues.text: Dp eo ©

dialogues.speaker: II-9
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: BENTLEY turns. You will tell me truly the nature of your interest in my people, and in Major Lawrence. FEISAL is serious, but BENTLEY grins disarmingly, like a caught out.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: It's very simple, sir. I'm looking for a hero.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (is amused) Indeed? You do not seem a romantic man?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Oh no. (again the "sincerity'"’) But certain influential men back home believe the time has come for America to add her weight to the ... the patriotic | struggle against Germany ... and Turkey. Now, I have been sent to find material which will show our people that this war is ... (he hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Enjoyable?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Hardly that, sir. But to show it in its , more adventurous aspects. After all your . Highness, war does wear such an aspect. Nobody deplores it more than... FEISAL is looking out of the window again. He interrupts

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: You are looking for a figure who will draw your country towards war?

dialogues.speaker: I-10
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (simply; hence with some dignity) All right, yes.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Aurens is your man.

dialogues.text: (innocently) Yes... AUDA shatters the camera against the carriage buffer, and dismissing BENTLEY from his mind as though he were a smal standing boy whose manners he has corrected, he says to L lowering a hand on his shoulder, with a blend ‘of affecti and reproof:

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: You are using up your nine lives very quickly. And goes, amidst approval and laughter. The noise of loot again.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (regarding the wreckage of his instrument) Charming company you keep.

dialogues.text: Auda?’ He's a bit old-fashioned. (he taps BENTLEY's other camera) He thinks these things will steal his virtue. (he is mounting the wreck- age again, helped by BENTLEY, who is not a bit put out as LAWRENCE adds, looking down) He thinks you're a sort of thief.

But as LAWRENCE (i.e. his feet) appr them they break off, look up and herald him so that as he swiftly along the wreck (lightly leaping the gaps between carriages) a mounting roar of acclamation rolls along wit thus glimpse: well dressed PASSENGERS, including a pair o CHILDREN with their PARENTS quickly disrobing themselves coats and shoes. A trio of CAVALRY OFFICERS must part wit their breeches, one already in his shirt-tails; let these preserve their dignity, the one in shirt-tails indeed cal acheroot; let there be a minimum of comic surprise and ou importance - other countries other customs. The BEDOUIN s by and eagerly collect the loot. TWO TURKISH STAFF OFFICE sit behind riddled windows as they died, upright. A BEDOU a bundle of clothing under one arm reaches up and removes cavalry coats from the rack over their heads. TRACKING PA the Third Class compartment we see clearly though fleetin dead or wounded. All the PASSENGERS, without exception, l and dead, are relieved of any items of clothing and bagga of any value. All along train, BEDOUIN hold up and shake rifles or items cf loot, as LAWRENCE passes_ and they join in the adulation. CHA TWO. OUR PARLIAMENT." The text begins: "Every Englishman has the vote. What does this mean? And how has it come ab And so on. BENTLEY looks up, finds ALI's stern but islightly uncomfo glance upon him.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: It is for children. I have set myself to learn again.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: What are you learning, from this?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Politics. He says this as one might say "Geometry", or "Latin". BEN at ease against the wheel, is interested; eyes him specul

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You going to be a democracy in this country? You going to have a Parliament?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (thinks; then gravely) I will tell you that, when I have a country. BENTLEY throws back his head in admiration and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: I-22
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (smiling) Did I answer well?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You answered without saying anything; that's politics. (he hands back the book, and says, agreeably) You learn quickly.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (gravely and respectfully) I have a good teacher.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Yeah! (This reminds him of a previous determination. He begins to rise) Yeah...

dialogues.text: In a smaller tent of unbleached yellow wool, LAWRENCE sit cross-legged in the attitude of a teacher. His head is ba focussed on an idea. At his feet isa map. He wears a vest camel trousers, all very white. His wound is now a matter and plaster merely. FARRAJ pops head and shoulders throug flap and says hastily:

dialogues.text: The man.

dialogues.text: Fine.  59

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (tugging his notebook from a side pocket and one of many pencils from his breast pocket) Before I return to the fleshpots, which I shall be very glad to do, may I put two questions to you, straight?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (grins at him) I'd be interested to hear you put a question straight, Mr. Bentley. BENTLEY chuckles. We should see that LAWRENCE has a sort respect for BENTLEY's intelligence and absolute freedom f principle as BENTLEY is fascinated by LAWRENCE's destruct scrupulosity. Also, in this sequence, we should see that has not stood up at all well to the campaigning: his clot become greasy and frayed, his skin chapped, he needs both anda shave. Whatever LAWRENCE is wearing by contrast shou virginally clean.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: One: What, in your opinion, do these people hope to gain from this war?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quiet, lightly) They hope to gain their freedom. BENTLEY looks at him cautiously. Freedom.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (scribbling, saying dryly, even sadly) ... they hope to gain their freedom ... There's one born every minute. Unseen by BENTLEY, LAWRENCE "freezes" at this and looks a vehemently.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: They're going to get it, Mr. Bentley. I'm going to give it to them. At the superhuman egoism of this BENTLEY looks up between and amusement, mouth open for a wise-crack, but he encoun i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 59 60 Tl-24 Continued LAWRENCE's poisonous regard and shuts it again, flummoxed

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (softly) : And the second question? ,

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Oh... well... Iwas going to ask... (he regains his professional manner firmly) What is it, Major Lawrence, that attracts you personally to the desert? LAWRENCE looks the disreputable figure up and down with i deliberation and says: .

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: It's clean. BENTLEY lowers his gaze tc his own garments. He lays down pad and pencil and when he looks up we expect him to be a resentful. Instead, he says in a voice that is dispassion thoughtful:

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Well, now that's a very illuminating answer. (he takes up his camera and says invitingly) May I take one farewell picture? CcUuT In the armoured car shelter. BRIGHTON is now there also. enters, boisterously. He carries a station clock with swi dulums. (we ought perhaps to have seen this item before, it as loot) He holds it up.

dialogues.text: I gave Muhmid Taud two lamps for it. One clock for two lamps.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (judiciously, but glancing at BRIGHTON) A fair bargain.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: "Fair\" I robbed him!

He tosses the clock from him. AUDA (cont) Trash. He lies on his "bed". I'must find something honourable.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Honourable! AUDA raises his head and considers BRIGHTON carefully. Th lies back again. He explains.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Yes. The year is running out 'Righton. I must find something honourable. And his face has the mindless nobility of a hungry lion. OPENING SHOT. Disclosing horses and panning with STALLION into reverse angle. LONG SHOT. From top rear of train with MACHINE GUNNERS in foreground. (A slight sense of boredom amongst Machine Gu Rig sun cover). dialogues.speaker: I-28
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT - AUDA. He turns into CAMERA. He is in ecstasy

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Now you may blow up my train. MEDIUM SHOT - He is standing by one of the armoured cars, on which are BRIGHTON, ALI, FARRAJ and LAWRENCE whom AUDA is addressing. Behind AUDA is his chaotic booty, drawing the train. At AUDA's words, LAWRENCE merely smiles a litt and looks down at his feet. From this point on, his atten wistfully but keenly and without self pity upon AUDA. He part in the discussion knowing that AUDA and BRIGHTON are too fixed in their own modes to understand one another; h remains on AUDA

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (hostile) And what will you do?

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Oh, now I go home! (he turns and takes in the scene, turns back again breathing deep with satisfaction) They will carry my toys! (he roars with laughter) They will carry my toys, too, do you see... BRIGHTON rises to his feet. He will take AUDA to task wit doubt and no more fear for his own safety than if he were prefect and AUDA an erring form mate.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Major Lawrence will campaign this winter. But you've got what you wanted, so you're going home; is that it? AUDA begins to see that something is wrong, but is as yet not angry.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Of course. (he pats LAWRENCE affectionately on the knee) When Aurens has got what he wants, he will go home! — ~ (encouragingly to

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: When you've got what you want you will go home!  © 69 70 71

dialogues.speaker: I-29
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Oh no I shan't, Auda.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (the tone of it now is unmistakeable and he apprehends it) Then you are a fool.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Maybe. I'm not a deserter. AUDA's face goes quite stiff, he blinks and licks his lip says very quitely:

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Give thanks to God, Brighton, that when he made you a fool, he gave you a fool's face. CLOSE SHOT - BRIGHTON, head and shoulders. He is not comi outraged, but he is affronted. He look straight at AUDA, forbidding, and (in his desert gear- sheepskin perhaps) t

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: You are an impudent rascal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must go Aurens. Before I soil myself with a fool's blood. And he goes towards his horse, quickly. BRIGHTON sits.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Like talking to a brick wall... CLOSE SHOT - AUDA mounted. He looks after his booty which this while has been driven away and away down the length and out into the desert under a cloud of dust. He turns. All gloom forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: They will carry my toys too! He rides away, watched by the group in the armoured car.  © “ “

dialogues.speaker: I-30
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT. THE GROUP. LAWRENCE looks steadily after AUDA BRIGHTON nods to himself and speaks with the bitter satis one whose worst fears are realised.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: So what willyou do now? What can you do? LAWRENCE tears his attention from the vanishing AUDA. He to collect demolition gear from the car. He speaks quietl

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'll go north ... Isn't that what Allenby wants?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (scoffing despair) Allenby wanted the "Arab Army" behind Deraa! LAWRENCE looks along the train where the remnants of his linger.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Then that's where I'll take it. He hands the demolition kit to FARRAJ, who nips eagerly f and waits for him. LAWRENCE following more slowly, adds:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Tell Allenby to hurry up or I'll be in Deraa before he's in Jerusalem. He puts a hand on FARRAJ, propélling him towards the engi says to him,. for BRIGHTON to hear: Won't we?

LAWRENCE and FARRAJ are busy on the line. Others watch, dispiritedly, or crouch against the wind, o a little pipe, fitfully.

LAWRENC him but FARRAJ works confidently and has obviously done i MAJID, crouching, watches him with grudging admiration. CLOSE SHOT. ALI looks straight down the line. He grunts s LAWRENCE joins him in frame. Neither shows apprehension n even much excitement. It is routine. EXTREME LONG SHOT - the plume of steam is barely visible. SOUND TRACK, LAWRENCE says: "Train, Farraj!"

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: (without excitement) Ya, Aurens. He has finished taping the pilot brick to the rail, holds of the tape which will be used to secure the secondary br one hand, and with the other inserts the plug. He looks a sees what he wants. CLOSE SHOT. A small red painted wooden box lies on a slee of reach. MEDIUM SHOT. MAJID steps over to it, picks it up and brin back. Doing so his foot slips on the edge of a sleeper. S FARRAdJ is on his feet to secure not the man but the box; so and for a second they are face to face, both holding i then they smile and the MAN let's go. FARRAJ takes from t one of the half dozen gleaming detenators, slides it.care the plug to see that it fits, then with that blend of car dexterity which marks the explosives man, he slips it int band (EXTREME CLOSE SHOT of this, I think) ‘and goes on w work. MEDIUM SHOT. LAWRENCE joins them. He collects together a coil of fuse, roll of tape, a small waterproof satchel of box, and hands them to MAJID, saying:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Hide yourself my friend. MEDIUM SHOT. THE RAIDERS are wandering away and disappear behind a hump very near to the line. ALI bringing up the at:  oO 83

We see that to do so he must plunge into a st into which he disappears before scaling the other side. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE, having taken over from FARRAJ, has finished taping the secondary bricks. Still no urgency.

LAWRENCE turns, still. crouching, to lo the line, and back at FARRAJ, who smiles embarrassedly an further. | MEDIUM SHOT. MAJID arrives behind the hump. This time, th RAIDERS are not poised for an attack. There is tension, n but each man crouches in the lee of his mount. Only ALI i watch. The PIPER continues, fitfully. ALI hisses him shar silence, and we hear for the first time the distant "puff the train. CLOSE SHOT. QUICK MEDIUM SHOT. THE TWO BEDOUIN scramble up the side o the ditch and run. MAJID looks up from the BOY.

dialogues.text: He cannot ride Aurens. Look.* He lifts from the BOY's stomach the blood soaked garments see for the first time. LAWRENCE goes down beside him. He as though hurled by a great blow in the face. ALI] AND MA towards him. WE HEAR THE TRAIN, now near, braking with a of metal and the singing dies out. QUICK .CLOSE SHOT. dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: If they take him alive, you know what they will do. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE backs away and throws his pistol to MAJID. CLOSE SHOT. MAJID looks at the pistol, smiles comprehendi shakes his head and rises away from FARRAJ. FARRAJ's breathing begins to come more and more rapidly w rising rhythm which must end in a scream. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE hurls himself on the pistol. MUSIC L CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE kneels by FARRAJ. Shouted orders from the TURKS. LAWRENCE stealthily brings the pistol tow FARRAJ's head. FARRAJ clutches his wrist instinctively. T smiles and lets go.

dialogues.speaker: FARRAJ
dialogues.text: Daud will be angry with you.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Salute him for me. He cannot doit. On SOUND TRACK the shouts draw closer. FARRAJ . (prompting kindly) God will give you peace. He turns his head away but does not close his eyes. MEDIUM SHOT. ALI AND MAJID wince away, turn, the pistol c out, they streak up the side of the ditch and run. LAWRENCE scrambles from the ditch and runs after them, hi fragmented.

dialogues.text: 103 Continued 1-35 ALI looks at LAWRENCE, is about to speak, thinks better o looks at him again and says, with much sympathy, as one w a question which cannot brook postponement even under suc stances as these:

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: What will you do, now? LAWRENCE clears his throat and answers flatly. Go north.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: ALI jogs on in silence for a beat or two. With twenty?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: We must see that ALI is genuinely exercised in his mind a there is any purpose in going on. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE's mask cracks. shouts:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: He turns to ALI and What would you recommend me to do, Ali? What would you recommend?

dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT. Interior ALLENBY's private apartments in Cai A spacious room with, at the far end, a working desk and nearer to the CAMERA a fireplace against which ALLENBY le and a few upholstered chairs in one of which BRIGHTON is It is night time and cosy lamps are li. (whereas before we have seen them spinning) and there is the grate. On the mantlepiece,by ALLENBY, the Country Lif calendar proclaims December with an Olde English hunting ALLENBY has a light plaid shawl thrown over his shoulders swills a whisky and soda in a large tumbler. The fans are motionless He is silently regarding BRIGHTON and though the professional maskis firmly in pla looks unusually thoughtful and a little triste. BRIGHTON, who has flung his Sam Browne on the back of his chair, and also h of whisky and soda at his elbow, is labouring through the sheaf of official reports. When he concludes, he hands th ALLENBY, with a grave face.  103 Continued

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: He hasn't one-tenth so many men, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Well, yes and no, sir... He doesn't claim to have done anything he hasn't done .

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Then there is an "Arab North Army".

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (considers) No, sir. He has lied about that.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Any idea why?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (with a half smile) It's his army, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (shortly) It's Prince Feisal'’s army ... Think he's gone native Harry?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (his brows puckered) N-n-n-0 -0-0. (with a flash of inspiration) He would if he could. (with a flash of self- doubt) I think. (uncomfortably) Not my line of country this, sir. He is puzzled by the mood of his CHIEF.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (reassuring) Doesn't matter ... I'm just curious. What matters is: I believed it and the Turks believe it. They're offering twenty-thousand pounds for him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Good God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 aw

dialogues.speaker: I-37 6
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (turns away - and CLOSE SHOT - prods idly at the fire with his toe) Yes. Shouldn't say he'd long to live would you?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (impulsively) Whatever else sir, he... !

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (interrupting rather impatiently) Oh surely, surely .... If he's still going North, with fifty men, he doesn't lack guts... : (brooding) I wonder if they'd offer that much for me... He turns briskly with the air of one who breaks off an im indulgence. Well, what about next year? Will they come back to him?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Shouldn't be surprised, sir. some kind of prophet. They think he's

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (harshly) They do or he does? He walks away to the working desk taking the paper with h back as he goes: They seem to think he's a kind of machine. Dryden had a letter from some old beggar behind Damascus; "Send us an Aurens and we will blow up trains with it". That's poetry, isn't it? And again his voice has a harsh sounding crack in it. BRIGHTON (On SOUND TRACK) (uneasy) I wouldn't know, sir.  Ty ees 0

dialogues.speaker: I-38
dialogues.text: 103 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: And that's what these are. (he wags the papers before throwing them down) Not lies, poems.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Don't quite follow, sir. 104 CLOSE SHOT. BRIGHTON, his care-worn, innocent face, c with the effort ta be in time with his chief.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (with a sudden rush of affection for things familiar) You're a good chap, Harry.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (a laugh is jerked out of him by the unexpected- ness of it) Thank you, sir!

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (approaching) Nice to have a fire again.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. 105 CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY by the fire, and again we see the

dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE SHOT - Interior. One of the bars of yellow is lying on a clean slab of stone. : CLOSE SHOT - LAWRENCE, wrapped in a torn grey blanket for warmth, is arranging his newly washed white robes over a improvised framework of sticks, to dry before a fire. He controlled nervousness. Nervousness is revealed in the me of his movements; control keeps them effective. MEDIUM SHOT - ALI, also in undress, smoking a cheroot, wa him, his face shows a distinct anger tempered by caution standing - in other words it shows a sober independence o which we have before seen only incipient. LAWRENCE knows waiting for him. ALI looks about, patiently. Cracks in th been stuffed with bits of rag, earth, grass in spite of w of snow spurt in .here and there. LAWRENCE straightens fr task, wiping his ands on a cloth.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (quietly) Now may I speak? LAWRENCE tr (cool) ' Yes. ALI is evidently repeating a point he has been trying to He speaks patiently.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: We are all tired.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (in a dead voice) — I'm not tired.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (flatly) You are tired.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (impatiently) _ All right, I'm tired... (attempts a sneer) it takes me differently.

dialogues.speaker: ALI .
dialogues.text: (calmly) | Truly .. Aurens, one more failure: and ® you will find yourself alone. |

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: So say they love you. The more reason to be thrifty with them. (he begins to appeal more urgently and grows excited immediatély) Give them something to do that can be done! ' But you... no, no, they must move mountains, for you, they must walk on water! i LAWRENCE's own much more racking, because more personal | - ignites from ALI's. He nods affirmatively to the last speech.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: : That's right! ..That's right !... he makes a pretence of going on wiping his hands but his set, pale face is still turned on his friend) Unwittingly, ALI has challenged him at the mingled root o and weakness and mustnow fate LAWRENCE's ‘whole persorial arms. wo Who are you to know what can be done? i If we'd done what you thought could be done you'd be back in 'Yenbo now, and nowhere! Whatever I ask them to do, can be done, that's all. .they know that if you don't... !

' Before ALI can reply, he turns from himtowards the openin in a voice ostensibly warm and confident with an unconsci of fear: My friends, who will walk on water with me? But reaching the doorway and looking in he realises that is more critical than he supposed. His expression.changes becomes alert, cautious. He realises that to get his own at any rate seem reasonable. : MEDIUM SHOT - what he sees. A small room of the Fort with charcoal | fire, the sodden robes of the BEDOUIN hanging dry. The BEDOUIN themselves seated in undress about the r their isaddles and sheepskins. They look both wild and gr veterans. All follow the ensuing debate most closely and except that MAJID cleans his rifle throughout. LAWRENCE l the doorway in a deliberately leisurely fashion and repea in a quiet and reasonable tone.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Who will come with me to Deraa? This suggestion does not take them by surprise; evidently heard of his intention and discussed it.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER HARITH
dialogues.text: Deraa is garrisoned. Will you take twenty against two thousand?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I'll go by myself if I have to.

dialogues.speaker: MAJID
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Because I told the English Generals ... the Arab Revolt would be in Deraa when they would be in Jerusalem.

dialogues.text: (he can't look at LAWRENCE but he persists) And are you the Arab Revolt? CLOSE SHOT - LAWRENCE looks round slowly. They avoid his

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) It begins to seem so.

dialogues.speaker: MAJID
dialogues.text: (softly) Or perhaps you are here for the English Generals? - LAWRENCE is profoundly shocked. It seems that he will l But then, challenging:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE

dialogues.speaker: ALI

dialogues.speaker: MAJID
dialogues.text: (regarding the spittle immediately) That, is not an argument.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (his face pale) Oh, argument! (he lashes them) This afternoon, I will take the Arab Revolt into Deraa... while the Arabs... argue. © (he turns and goes) 7
