From the sympathetic warmth of tone the keenness with which he regards him we see that LAWREN behavior has already aroused anxiety. He follows LAWRENCE eyes. There is the SOUND of a door opening. 'S 176 CLOSE SHOT - the door. (From inside ALLENBY's room LAWRENCE enters. He stops short, his face blank. The Engl theme ends abruptly on a barbaric dissonance of cymbals. 177 MEDIUM SHOT -a figure in full Arab regalia is more or oO silhouetted against an open archway letting out on to , over-looking a garden. As the:reverberations of the cym away. this figure turns and we see it is FEISAL, and that and DRYDEN are also present. The CAMERA PANS with FEISAL he walks towards LAWRENCE smiling courteously. eo FEISAL (sponteneous pleasure) M Aurens! , He joins LAWRENCE in CLOSE SHOT and seizes him by the h © but as he does so the glow fades from his face and is r sadness and suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: or is it Major Lawrence? i

dialogues.speaker: / LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (saluting: formally) Sir. 178 CLOSE SHOT - ALLENBY and DRYDEN. Their eyes on LAWREN © 129 CLOSE SHOT - FEISAL and LAWRENCE.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (dropping his hand) ) The CAMERA PANS with FEISAL as he leaves LAWRENCE and m towards ALLENBY and DRYDEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tl-62 179 Continued

dialogues.speaker: . FEISAL
dialogues.text: Well I will leave you, General. Major Lawrence doubtless has reports to make. He goes towards a glass door leading directly out on to t ¢orridor, but pauses to deliver his salvoes.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: About my people; and their wealmess. And the need to keep them weak. In the British interest. (by the door) The French interest too of course, we mustn't forget the French, now. 180 CLOSE UP - ALLENBY. He is exasperated.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: I've told you, sir no such treaty exists.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Yes, General, you have lied most bravely, But not convincingly. I know this treaty. does exist.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Treaty, sir?

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: He does it better than you, General. (bitterly) But then of course - he's almost an Arab, He sweeps out through the door. 184 CLOSE SHOT - LAWRENCE. There isa silence. He looks fr the door to ALLENBY and DRYDEN..

dialogues.speaker: I-63
dialogues.text: 185 MEDIUM SHOT ALLENBY, LAWRENCE and DRYDEN. DRYDEN looks curiously and keenly at LAWRENCE.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: You really don't know? LAWRENCE spreads his hands to demonstrate complete incomp sion but he is already looking concerned.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Then what the devils this? He holds up a paper scrumpled in his fist.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (his tone is one of total exhaustion in a thin shell of correctness) It's my request for release from Arabia, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (angry) For what reason! (suspicious ) Are you sure you haven't heard of the Sykes-Picot Treaty?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No. (wearily) Ican guess, 187 CLOSE SHOT ALLENBY and DRYDEN

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (sharply) Don't guess. (to DRYDEN) Tell him. DRYDEN steeples his fingers delicately.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Well now, Mr. Sykes is an English Civil Serveant and Monsieur Picot is a French

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 187 Continued DRYDEN (cont) Civil Servant. Mr. Sykes and Monsieur Picot met. And they agreed that, after the war, France and England should share the Turkish Empire. Including Arabia. They signed an agreement - : (he glances at

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: 7 notatreaty, sir, an Agreement --- to that effect.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: There may be honour among thieves but there's none in politicians. 189 CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY and DRYDEN 190 igi

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (when, as now, he is stung, he is quite deadly) : And let's have no displays of indignation. You may not have known, but you certainly’ had suspicions. He rises and walks away towards the archway over-looking If we've told lies you've told half-lies ... And a man who tells lies -~- like me --- merely hides the truth. (softly) But a man who tells half-lies ... has forgotten where he put it.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Right. But I met a man the other day; who showed me where it was. The truth is I'm an ordinary man. You might have told me that, Dryden. MEDIUM: SHOT. OVER LAWRENCE on to ALLENBY and DRYDEN DRYDEN looks at him, curiously and cautiously. LAWRENCE t ALLENBY and says with a change of tone, officially but wi tone of threat almost, anticipating opposition:  ce 192 193 o 1-65

dialogues.speaker: CY
dialogues.text: bod 191 Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: And I want an ordinary job, sir. That's my reason for resigning. ALLENBY wrinkles his face irritably and grunts interrogat and LAWRENCE raises his voice by a desperate little physi It's... personal!

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (softly and irritably. as though LAWRENCE was not speaking clearly) Personal?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (starting quietly but incredulous indignation _ breaking through) . Personal? You're a Serving Officer in the Field! And as it happens a damned important one! Personal? Are you mad? CLOSE UP LAWRENCE. HE is sweating and every muscle in his body is rigid, andhis voice comes high and strained.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No, and if you don't mind I'd rather not go mad! That's my reason too! CLOSE SHOT ALLENBY has his own strains and he leaps from his chair, the CAMERA PANNING with him to the window on t side of the room from DRYDEN. He stands silently, his bac CAMERA, making and effort to contain himself.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Look Lawrence ..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: oO : ALLENBY (off) -.- on the 16th April I'm making my big push on Damascus. And you're part of it.

dialogues.speaker: I-66
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP. ALLENBY. He turns to face LAWRENCE.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (explasive) Can you understand that? You're an important part of the big push! CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE. He-is shaking and as he pumps out each separated word he jerks his clenched fists up and do his sides.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I-- don't ~~ want to be -- part of your -- big push! . CLOSE UP. DRYDEN. He has been looking away out into the garden, but now he turns his head slowly to look at the t ALLENBY (off) And what about your Arab friends? What about them? LAWRENCE (off) I have -~ no -- Arab friends! I don't want Arab friends! DRYDEN's eyes widen and he stares. MEDIUM SHOT. From DRYDEN's point ot view we see LAWRENCE' back in the foreground of picture with ALLENBY standing f him at the window in the background. Regular streaks of b have appeared across the back of LAWRENCE's too tight jac He has opened the wounds of his flogging.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (more quietly) What in hell do you want, Lawrence?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quieter) I've told you; I just want my ration of common humanity. DRYDEN (off) (carefully offhand but very clear) Lawrence.  fn we 198 199 200 -67 Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (turning) Yes? ALLENBY sees what DRYDEN has seen. CLOSE SHOT DRYDEN. He sees that ALLENBY has seen.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: No, nothing, sorry I interrupted, sir. MEDIUM SHOT. LAWRENCE in foreground, ALLENBY in background. LAWRENCE, wary and puzzled, turns back to ALLENBY who moves forward towards him with an utter chang of tone, shocked but thinking furiously.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Quite all right... er. Thank you, Mr Dryden. DRYDEN crosses picture as he goes swiftly towards the doo BRIGHTON's office.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir. ALLENBY takes LAWRENCE by the arm and propels him towards the archway leading on to the terrace.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: ‘Er, why don't we... ? The CAMERA PANS with them. We see DRYDEN shutting the doo in the background.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (quickly and discreetly) Your back's covered with blood. LAWRENCE's hand flies up behind his back. ALLENBY continu sympathetic but with a calm which is complimentary to LAW D'you want a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: I-68
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (after a quick glance at his face to check his condition, seriously) Well tell me what's happened. They go through on to the TERRACE where there are chairs, asmall table, drinks, magazines and newspapers. MEDIUM SHOT. The ORDERLY ROOM. BENTLEY, watched contemptuously by the R.S.M, and ORDERLIES, is trying qui openly, and indifferent to their opinion, to hear at the BRIGHTON'S OFFICE. This is opened suddenly by DRYDEN. His face is shocked and gloomy and he takes no more notic BENTLEY than if he were a waste paper basket. CLOSE SHOT. DRYDEN and BENTLEY in the foreground; BRIGHTON seen through the open door in the background. He staring at DRYDEN, shocked and anxious.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Shall I get a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: A doctor? No.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (rather fearfully) Will I be wanted?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: No, Harry. Not you... DRYDEN closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Say, what goes on in there? DRYDEN commences to walk away from him.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Nothing. BENTLEY follows.  e 202

dialogues.speaker: TI-69
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (briskly, dismissing the formalities of discretion) Ah come on.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (with an exaggerated insouciance which isn't meant to be believed) No really, nothing at all.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Is the man in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (BENTLEY's question has come near the quick of his feelings; his face is a shade less bland as he murmurs lightly) Oh I expect so. We're all in trouble. Life! a vale of troubles. BENTLEY overtakes him round a desk and bars his way, adop a coaxing tone of voice to mitigate the offensiveness of budging.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Just tell me if the man's in trouble. I've got an interest in the man. I've got a claim.

dialogues.speaker: _ DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (cold, contemptuous and sharp) What claim?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (deprecating shrug) You've read my stuff -- I've made that boy a hero. (as one who advances a righteous claim) When the war's over that boy can be anything he wants!

dialogues.speaker: TI-70
dialogues.text: 202 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (trying to side-step BENTLEY, who foils him) Yes; well at the moment he wants to be somebody else. (suddenly incensed) Will you kindly allow me to pass? BENTLEY does so, but, lounging deliberately, speaks delib after him.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Walk away, Dryden, walk away. Always walking away, aren't you? :

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (at the door, caught unprepared for the penetration of this, frowns a little, hesitates) Well, I'll tell you. It's a little clash of temp- eraments that's going on in there. Inevitably. One of them's half mad. (he had intended to finish there but adds) And the other -- wholly wmscrupulous. He reaches the door and goes out into the sunlight. 203 MEDIUM SHOT. THE. TERRACE outside ALLENBY'S OFFICE. LAWRENCE is seated in a chair. ALLENBY leaning against a pillar, his bottom on the terrace railing.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: ++. Yes. Well you've had a glimpse of the pit.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No, a glimpse. of sanity. . (hard) And I'm not going back. There is a short pause. LAWRENCE's eyes are on the Genera epaulettes. ALLENBY notices the look, glances at his crow crossed .swords,, and begins to unbutton his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: I-71
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: You won't go mad, Lawrence. (quite indifferently) You've got an iron mind.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (grimly) Oh no. (but he is pleased)

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Oh yes.. And here’s another thing. When you ask for "common humanity" you're crying for the moon. Common humanity's the one thing you can't have.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: There's nothing else.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (mildly) There is, for one man every hundred years or so.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (sceptical, but we can just see the poison beginning to work) Me?

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (taking off his jacket) Yes, I think so. (Again he is careful to keep his voice matter-of-fact, as were some small technical judgement he had just made. ) ALLENBY puts his jacket over the back of an empty chair, from this point on he adopts the tone used between equals and friends of such long standing ‘that they can even aff brusque. He regards his jacket, chucklinga little ruefull

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Isn't that funny, I feel quite naked. He busies himself collecting cigar,cutter, matches from t

dialogues.speaker: I-72
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: And that's the difference. I'm a leader because someone pins crowns on me. You're a leader, : (shrugs) because God made you one I suppose. There's nothing you can do about it. ALLENBY sits and seems totally preoccupied with the condi his cigar. LAWRENCE does not answer but looks at him susp flattered, comforted, above all longing to accept the pat that seems to be offered.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (quite idly) You write poems don't you?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes ‘ALLENBY Any good?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No. Bad.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (nods sympathetically) Hard luck. LAWRENCE is a little amused and quite surprised by the de of understanding ALLENBY assumes.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: It's not a matter of luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘Course it is. (he settles back comfortably) I grow dahlias myself. Apparently on impulse he takes from the table a photo of and offspring. He peers at it, pointing out a patch of ca in the background.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: There.

dialogues.speaker: I-73
dialogues.text: 1° 203 Continued Together they study the photo. ALLENBY never looks once a victim, seems innocently absorbed in the subject of the c He pauses as he replaces the photo, and smiles. 9°

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: That's my lad. You must come and see us, ree ' afterwards. © _ LAWRENCE (he hesitates cautiously, but says) I'd like to. And it is almost like a physical object he has handed to © the keys of his citadel.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: I've got good soil, good compost, I buy good plants. And I'm a conscientious 6S gardener. But don't have the luck to ‘ be a good one.. So (he grins) : I'm a gardening sort of general. Most . generals are. But there have been poet © generals. Xenophon was one. Hannibal ... Nelson was the last. I think you're another...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (his tone sceptical a but his smile tremulous and reproachful) Nelson, and me? He is asking ALLENBY to be merciful.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: © That's an extraordinary thing to say to : a man. nn)

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Not to an extraordinary man it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 203 Continued He makes this statement very deliberate.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (thrusting it away from him) No. No.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (remorselessly matter- of-fact) You must Imow it?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (almost desperately) No!

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (in his cunning adopts a tone of irritation) Look, Lawrence, I've taken those things off -- (rubs his shoulder) -- and I don't feel happy without them. I believe your name will be a household word when you'd have to go to the War Museum to find who Allenby was. His voice now becomes low, confidential, but very steady; it is temptation inca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLENBY (off) You are the most extraordinary man I ever met.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quick and low) -- leave me alone -- ALLENBY (off) (quick and sharp) --What?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (quick and low) -- Leave me alone.  205 206 207 208

dialogues.speaker: I-75
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY over LAWRENCE. After a pause, ALLENBY shrugs, and the CAMERA PANS with him as he rises and move with feigned hostility, turning his back looking out over the very image of a disappointed father.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: That's a feeble thing to say. No wonder your poetry's bad.” CLOSE UP. LAWRENCE looks at ALLENBY's back longingly. He hesitates and is lost. He prevaricates:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I know I'm not ordinary... ALLENBY (off) (short) That's not what I'm saying. Suddenly LAWRENCE's immobility flies apart. He is thrown in his chair by muscular stresses ~- much as 2 man might to a thumbscrew -~ and he cries out:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: All right I'm extraordinary! I'm extraordinary! His tone in saying this is as though he were saying, “All got cancer!" A tone of desperate lament... But then abrup accepted it, he freezes again and looking at ALLENBY he s avery different tone quietly mocking, from a superior kno

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: What of it? CLOSE UP. ALLENBY. He is now looking at LAWRENCE, but has not yet caught the reversal of their positions.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (gravely and kindly) Not many people have a destiny. Lawrence. A terrible thing for a man, to funk it, if he has. MEDIUM.SHOT. ALLENBY walks back towards his chair.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (almost smiling with a little cold smile) Are you speaking from experience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 0-76 Continued

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (caught in mid-air -- he sits) No.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: You're guessing then. ALLENBY is nonplussed and begins to be uneasy. LAWRENCE s in a deadly voice.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Suppose you're wrong.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (briskly scrambles over his unease) Why suppose that? We both know I'm right.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: After all, it's --- LAWRENCE interrupts him rising from his chair and walking paces along the terrace where he stands in an archway his the General.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I said, yes. ALLENBY watches him, cautiously. He turns. He addresses ALLENBY quite politely but not looking at him, as though a subordinate.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: April the 16th.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Yes. Can you doit. I'll give you a lot of money.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (still not looking) Artillery?

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: T can't.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (now looking at him) They won't be coming for money, the best of them. They'll be coming for Damascus. (very steadily) Which I'm going to give them. CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY looking up at LAWRENCE from his chair He blinks, but recovers immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all I want.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: All you want is someone holding down. the Turkish Right. But I'm going to give them Damascus. We'll get there before you do. And when they've got it, they'll keep it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAWRENCE (off) You can tell the politicians to burn their bit of paper, now.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (spuriously boisterous) Fair enough! CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. He looks away from ALLENBY and speaks almost idly, throwing his pearls for ALLENBY to pi he can.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: "Fair". What's "fair" got to do with it? It's going to happen... (looking at him again, quite brisk and matter of fact) I shall want quite a lot of money.  c 212 213 214 215 216

dialogues.speaker: T-78
dialogues.text: Continued ALLENBY (off) All there is!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Not that much. He leaves the courtyard and walks towards the CAMERA, loo up in the frame against the background of a fresco on the

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: The best of them won't come for money. He is now in BIG CLOSE UP. His lip quivers slightly and h glow.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: They'll come for me... LONG SHOT. Angling down the ARAB ARMY ASSEMBLED. They are in two long lines, very well ordered. In front of their m Sheiks either sit their beasts or stand beside them ready their Standard Bearers behind them. The camels are kneeli riders ready. The HORSEMAN nearest CAMERA look off (past CAMERA) stiffens, standing in his stirrups. He raises his a shrill cry. EXTREME LONG SHOT. Over the level land something is appro LONG SHOT. Angling down the Army as before. With murmurou excitement camels rear up, horsemen mount, all together s the whole line rises in one movement. At the far end of t formed by the lines are two isolated horsemen, and a van man on the roof drives out and joins them. (About this va a civilian, not an army vehicle - something Bentley has b borrowed or stolen. I would even say it should have lette Mkapolous and Son, Gordon St., Alexandria, Finest Fresh B Delivered". It is vital in this scene to signal to the au are not offering magnificence in lieu of a properly contr like a Charlton Heston Sampson and Delilah, that we the f do not take it at face value. Bentley is the vitalizing p ance in this epic atmosphere which he will enrich, not de use him bodily. Nothing like a streak of low comedy runni a scene of high drama - vide the late William Shakespeare MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT. The man on the roof is BENTLEY, with a tripod camera. The two horsemen are ALI and AUDA.  Oo 216 Continued 01-79

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: No pictures! You take no pictures of us!

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: It's not for you Sheik Auda, it's for Major Lawrence; he doesn't mind having his picture taken. (he adds for ALI’s benefit) He doesn't. mind at all. AUDA knows this is true and he regards it as a fault. He himself from this offensive man a few yards, grumbling:

dialogues.speaker: . , AUDA
dialogues.text: Well... There is only one Aurens... And staring keenly off towards: 217 LONG SHOT. As for 214 but the moving object is now se a bunch of camel men, riding rapidly, a white figure amon 218 MEDIUM SHOT. BENTLEY and ALI. BENTLEY ostensibly busi himself with his camera, says lightly:

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: You, erm, met Major Lawrence since he came back, Sherif?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Yes. ‘

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Changed, hasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (loyally) No.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: Oh I'd say he had. Different man, I'd say. 219 LONG SHOT. Exactly as for 214 and 217 but we can now

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: 220 BENTLEY and ALI, as before.  220 Continued

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: What did that Turkish General do to him, in Deraa?_

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (fighting down his own fear, with . anger) : He was the same man after Deraa... the same man humbled! “(the humbleness was an added virtue evidently) What did the English General do to him, in Jerusalem?

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (amused and pleased by ALI's percipience) Seach me. Ask Aurens. 221 LONG SHOT as for 214, 217, 219, but now LAWRENCE and are nearly at the entrance to the corridor. 222 BENTLEY and ALI, as before.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: He laughed ... He told me to gather the Harith, here... He offered me money.

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: (chirpily ignoring ALI's .deep and apprehensive tone) D'you take it?

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: No. But many did. 223 MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE and his BODYGUARD ride between the ranks. (On SOUND TRACK the Tribesmen break into adulation, some shouting his name, some simply shouting, is a gradually rising fury of sound underlain by the chan  223 224 225 226 227 228 229 230 231

dialogues.speaker: I-81
dialogues.text: Continued as he progresses) They ride tightly bunched, not filling LAWRENCE is at the head, but definitely one of them, not He is mounted on a magnificent white camel, outrageously though he himself is still all white. His expression is e have seen before. But it is also unwittingly desperate - aware of himself, imperfectly in control of himself - and not seen before. The BODYGUARD ride beautifully, every ma expert. LAWRENCE turns his eyes from side to side, taking Army, but the BODYGUARD keep: their brutalized faces immo save perhaps for a faint suggestion of a sneer, a secret joke. They are contemptuous of all this merely legitmate Outsiders who have sold themselves to LAWRENCE, they conc themselves with him only. They are all ofa kind. They are dressed, armed to the tetth. TRACK SHOT. Along the face of the ARAB ARMY. We now see t behind and among the Tribesmen are men of a different kin on mules, even donkeys, some very poorly dressed, in lite rags, one or two doubled up on rangy farm camels. But all and bandoliers - British Arm Webbing in the case of the p are in a state of wild excitement, but we now pass a Shei horse before his men, and as he sees LAWRENCE's party : PANNING SHOT. LAWRENCE and BODYGUARD P.O.V. the SHEIK. As for 224. The SHEIK looks horrified, bewildered, alarme contrast to the open mouths, staring eyes and wildly flap behind him. As for 223, LAWRENCE and BODYGUARD. As for 224 TRACKING ALONG the Arab Army. Another Sheik wi same reaction. As for 223 and 227. LAWRENCE and BODYGUARD. As for 224 and 228, TRACKING. dialogues.text: 232. MEDIUM SHOT. A large British Army tent, Interior. It on bare earth by the road to DAMASCUS. Outside we hear a band receding "Goodbye Tipperary", and the regular tramp and motor vehicles in low gear: a Brigade going up to the ALLENBY sits at a camp table on a camp chair in an attitu enforced patience, stirring a cup of tea. His dress exhib little personal irregularities which Officers permit them active service. 233. REVERSE SHOT. Before him sit four groups of high ran OFFICERS at.four tables littered with papers. The largest Infantry, administrative and thoughtful; the next Artille at.the next Cavalry, conscientiously dashing, booted legs finally the Specialists --- Native Affairs, Allied Liaiso Signals.. At the moment every one of these important men  eS ‘I-85 Continued stirring a cup of tea and staring sternly at the CAMERA ( ALLENBY) except for the Artillery table which is even now served from a large tray by. a white-coated Arab SERVANT, then goes, through the flap which is whipped open and shu him by a Military Policeman on guard outside. At once:

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY GENERAL
dialogues.text: (on his feet --- a man with a fierce moustache to single him out) If the enemy's retreating in any kind of order --- which we'd better assume ---?

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: --- Certainly ---

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY GENERAL
dialogues.text: Then he can't be further than --- (glances at map before him) --- this Mallud place. In which case I can have him within range by (a moment's pause before he commits himself) 0900 hours tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (his face lights up) Splendid! All eyes turn on the INFANTRY GENERAL. A more cautious sp  © v

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: That'll do for now. (to ARTILLERY GENERAL) The guns are what matter.

dialogues.speaker: ARTILLERY GENERAL
dialogues.text: (quietly reassuring) Understood sir.

dialogues.speaker: CAVALRY GENERAL
dialogues.text: (rather superior,. rising from map) This "Arab Army" on the Right sir, What's it consist of?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (addressing him) Irregular cavalry, sir; about two thousand.

dialogues.speaker: CAVALRY GENERAL
dialogues.text: And where are they now?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (almost proudly) Can only know that by being with them sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (rising. A little irritable) Then get with them Harry; I want to know.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Yes sir. ALLENBY goes, breaking up the meeting; his gait shows he specific task awaiting elsewhere but he pauses by the ART GENERAL to take his arm and murmur:

He stops when he comes upon: CLOSE SHOT. A BEDOUIN removing the boots from a group of corpses. He takes up his rifle and shoots the TURK. CLOSE SHOT. The MAN ON THE DONKEY leaves the dust and mak for open country. The moon is rising. CLOSE SHOT. Three or four BEDOUIN trot silently, their ri ready. CLOSE SHOT. A heap of dead donkeys, tangled in the harnes turned little trucks, coughing is heard in the dust. CLOSE SHOT. A BODYGUARD cocks his head and listens intent to the coughing; a pistol in his hands. MEDIUM LONG SHOT. THE MAN ON THE DONKEY, out in the open. CLOSE SHOT. AUDA sees, takes off after him. CLOSESHOT. The man hears AUDA COMING. He spurs his donkey MEDIUM SHOT. The MAN ON THE DONKEY towards us. AUDA is coming up behind him. When the TURK is right up to the CA AUDA is right up with him and for a second fills the scre CLOSE SHOT. AUDA reins. in; the dead TURK behind him; the donkey standing. AUDA sheathes his sword, takes out his r shoots the donkey. CLOSE SHOT. His graphic face is merciless and stern but n It is the face of Mars satisfied. EXTREME LONG SHOT, The moon has risen clear and lovely ab the hills. CAMERA pans round the hills to: MEDIUM SHOT. LAWRENCE onan eminence, mounted on his camel looking over what he has done, which we have not yet seen in a parallel stance but removed at a distance from him.  ) . 0-99 A J 359 MEDIUM SHOT. Behind them BENTLEY approaches on a © ' camel with a dilapidated saddle, precariously hanging comical figure. ' 360 CLOSE SHOT. He shouts out: (he is eager for his sto o BENTLEY Hey, Major! Major Lawrence! , He slithers down protecting his camera, not himself, an incline panting. But when he sees what is to be seen his '© changes: Jesus wept! This is an expression of pure shock, but after a pause hi , a fund of natural pity and the sadness of his too wide ,O little understood. Deeply and simply:

dialogues.speaker: BENTLEY
dialogues.text: . Jesus wept ..... Sa 361 LONGSHOT. With a chord of MUSIC we see the field o ‘ half-stripped bodies of the TURKS lie like ivory in the swathes and rows. It is a Golgotha. A few ARABS. make the them, stooping. From this distance ALI calls, his voice c bitterness.

dialogues.speaker: . ALI
dialogues.text: Does it suprise you, Mr. Bentley? : CAMERA approaches him. Wo Surely you know the Arabs are a barbarous people! ... Barbarous and cruel? Who but they ----? (He swallows) Who but they ----- 2 Cc (He breaks off) 362 CLOSE SHOT. BENTLEY, looking up at the mounted figure LAWRENCE in a tone not of hatred or disgust, but of lamen fallen hero: © BENTLEY Oh, you rotten man. He aims his camera, and we see LAWRENCE from his viewpoin magnificent and romantic figure against the sky, and hims O like an inferior animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 362 363 364 365 366 367 -100 Continued BENTLEY (cont) Here. Let me take your rotten bloody picture. He does so and aims his camera again. For the rotten bloody newspapers. LAWRENCE suffers it, his face like marble in the magnesiu

dialogues.speaker: CUT ,
dialogues.text: CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. A galloping ARAB HORSEMAN. He carris a bunch of unripe grapes.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: LAWRENCE as before, but now entirely alone. The horseman and holds out the grapes.

dialogues.speaker: HORSEMAN
dialogues.text: (triumphant) These were cut last night Aurens --- : in Damascus! ' CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. He takes them and stares at them. EXTREME CLOSE SHOT. The translucent green beads of fruit in his hands, while on SOUND TRACK the HORSEMAN repeats i "Damascus" One or two of the grapes break off and lie in LAWRENCE's MEDIUM SHOT. LAWRENCE hands the bunch back to the HORSEMA and regards them in the HORSEMAN's hands.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (in a voice perfectly prosaic, perfectly null, the voice of Aircraftsman Shaw) . Take them to Sherif Ali. Tell him... remind him... He takes a shuddering breath and looks away hoplessly. Th turns his horse. LAWRENCE's eyes fall upon the grapes in

dialogues.speaker: T-101
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Is Allenby in Damascus?

dialogues.speaker: HORSEMAN
dialogues.text: (looking at him curiously) Near.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Tell Sherif Ali that. He cuts off his awareness of the man.. Slowly and mechani puts the grapes in his mouth. The expression of his haunt does not change one iota but his lips twitch in a reflex bitterness of the fruit.

dialogues.speaker: HORSEMAN
dialogues.text: (laughing) They are not ripe! The HORSEMAN goes. cut CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY is striding, a conquering Caesar, thr his improvised Headquarters in Damascus. CAMERA retreatin him. At one elbow walks BRIGHTON, at the other a MAJOR. B are the A.D.C, and DRYDEN. Having this very minute arrive ALLENBY is travel-stained and tired looking, and carries The A.D.C, likewise. DRYDEN carries his Panama hat and st looks fatigued, though immaculate. The MAJOR and BRIGHTON been there some time, are cleaner and without their caps, BRIGHTON is also without Sam Browne or jacket. The MAJORi sort of Military Major-Domo, fussy and self-important, an showing ALLENBY to his quarters. He runs ahead to open do indicates to left and right the preparations that are bei the halls through which they pass. He has an exact half o attention; BRIGHTON has the other. Trestle tables and cha carried in one after another; papers, typewriters and fil and ordered by a host of Clerical N.C.O.'s, while Signalm unwind spools of telephone cable in contrary directions. voices and the banging and slapping of their equipment, ( not excited) makes a constant echoing and we can only hea BRIGHTON is talking urgently, a "rhubarb" speech which we hear except the underlined words:  368 369 370 371

dialogues.speaker: H-102 '
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Lawrence is behind it sir --- everything they ' do on the advice of Lawrence! Everything that matters is swarming with the Arab Army -- They've got a thing they call the Arab Flag: I don't know how they did it --- know who ' did it for them --- Lawrence! \ CLOSE SHOT. The MAJOR passes the CAMERA. ;

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (to BRIGHTON) When?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: A day and a night, sir' They've been ' here a day anda night! They've occupied the town, sir! They've done it! He's set up his own Headquarters -~- in the Town Hall! He is almost querulous at ALLENBY's continuing equanimity divided attention. ALLENBY pauses to pick up a telephone for the "live" tone, and then replaces it, before passing

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: What else besides the Town Hall?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Telephone Exchange, Post Office, Power House. (He indicates the electric light beneath which they are passing) Hospitals, Fire Stations, everything, sir! REVERSE SHOT. The MAJOR rather grandly throws open a doub door, steps back and salutes. as the party. passes throug MEDIUM SHOT. Inside ALLENBY's temporary private quarters. Two rooms, the first a living room. The A.D.C. shuts the on the MAJOR and on the racket outside.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: They call themselves the Arab National Council, sir!  "oO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 371 372 373 -108 Continued But ALLENBY throws down his cap and walks straight throug (CAMERA FOLLOWING) to the next room, very sparsely furnis with wash-stand and camp bed which he tests without enthu BRIGHTON's voice pursues him, reiterating indignant and b as though this were proof of the urgency of the situation BRIGHTON (on SOUND TRACK) They're in the Town Hall! ALLENBY comes back into the living room saying:

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Well they're your pigeon, Harry. What do you think we should do then?

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: Well, get 'em out of there, in quick time, sir!

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: How about that, Dryden?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Not unless you want a full-scale rising on your hands.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (to DRYDEN) Well what then? CLOSE SHOT. DRYDEN looking over the green palms and garde Damascus. We hear distant crowd noises.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (to ALLENBY) When will. Prince Feisal be in Damascus? MEDIUM SHOT. All looking at DRYDEN.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: By special train in two days' time.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (calculating) Two days...

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Two days is what you asked me for. I can't keep him out any longer. Isn't it enough?  co 373 c 374

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -104 Continued

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (almost sadly) Yes, ample I should think. MEDIUM SHOT .as before.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (puzzled and indignant) We can't just do nothing, sir! This cry breaks the stillness. The A,D.C. relaxes his pos attention. DRYDEN moves from the window towards a chair. sits and says to BRIGHTON, smiling:

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Why not? It's usually best. (to A.D.C.) Get us something to drink, Tracey. A.D.C. moves towards door. And Tracey: All troops to remain quartered until further orders. A.D.C. Yes sir. (Pauses) . Does that apply to Technical Units, sir

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Technical Units particularly. A.D.C. Yes, sir. (Going)

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (a little horrified) Medicals, too, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (harsh) Yes, Harry, Medicals too! CcuT

dialogues.speaker: T-105
dialogues.text: THE COUNCIL CHAMBER of the Town Hall. Pandemonium reigns. Some two dozen of the leading SHEIKS are seated (or stand long mahogany table. At its head the principal chair --- throne -~- is unoccupied. On one side of it is LAWRENCE's on the other, ALI's. AUDA is by LAWRENCE. The others rang down the table and their rifles make a small arsenal down polished surface. Absurdly, ink stands, paper and pens ha placed along it, but these are now pushed away and scatte dignitaries, in European clothes and the Turkish fez look the walls. At the foot of the table on bentwood chairs br the occasion, are one or two SYRIANS in pale suits, with collars. One or two of the SHEIKS look grave, one or two most are in a mood of total excitement and uncontrol. Rou ranged their individual BODYGUARDS --- say three or four SHEIK --- armed to the teeth and ready to back their mast blows, bullets or as now merely with noise. At the moment SHEIKS are in two factions, leaning across the table or t other on the same side, shouting fiercely. Some of LAWREN BODYGUARD are by the door which trembles now and then und from without, LAWRENCE is seated staring at the table wit premonition of defeat. AUDA, beside himself with rage, is yelling into ALI's face. ALI is seated, his face grim wit and the effort of self control. We cannot hear what AUDA "Howeitat" and, repeatedly, 'Harith". LAWRENCE looks up, himself, rises suddenly and pounds the table with the but leaving dents in the surface. He goes on, looking fiercel SHEIKS, until (the graver souls pulling the others into t are sufficiently silent and mostly seated.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: We here are neither, Harith nor Howeitat, nor any other tribe but Arabs of the Arab Council, acting for Prince Feisal! This momentarily calms all with the parcial exception of glaring at ALI says:

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: He insulted me! An ominous murmur from Howeitat supporters.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (patiently) Sherif Ali said that the telephones are in the care of the Howeitat and that the telephones have ceased to work. And this is true, Auda.  O..

dialogues.speaker: I- 106
dialogues.text: Continued , !

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (sullenly) : They will not work because they are given | no electricity. And the electricity is in the care of the Harith! (to ALI) You insulted me --- Harith! This last word is said as aterm of abuse. ALI starts and grips his wrist.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (to ALI, sotto but not looking . at him) If you answer they'll be bloodshed.

dialogues.speaker: ALI \
dialogues.text: (looks at LAWRENCE: sotto) Do you speak to me of bloodshed? LAWRENCE takes this in. He releases ALI's hand which is r ALI raises his voice: . . ‘ I ask pardon of AudaIbu Tayi. AUDA raises his eyebrows. He is astonished. Then he sneer

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Humbly? Humbly, Harith? . i ALI licks his lips, clenches his fists upon the table end AUDA, ‘replies: .

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Yes. AUDA looking at him, sees that his motive is not fear. He filled with unease and depression.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Weil, this is a new trick... He throws himself back gloomily in his chair. LAWRENCE qu seizes the opportunity to break the train of events. He a ELDER HARITH: o,f

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Why is there no electricityfor the telephones?  as 375 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tf-107 Continued ELDER HARITH rises for a speech. A respected figure, he h attention particularly of the older and graver spirits.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER HARITH
dialogues.text: I have been to the Electrical House Aurens. There are three large machines ... A SYRIAN, patronisingly helpful calls up the table to LAW

dialogues.speaker: SYRIAN
dialogues.text: He means generators.

dialogues.speaker: ELDER HARITH
dialogues.text: (Courteously) So? (to LAWRENCE) One of them is burning. (He turns to the others, smiling pityingly) They are of incredible size, but helpless.

dialogues.speaker: WHITE HAIRED SHEIK
dialogues.text: (sententiously) It is so with all machines.

dialogues.speaker: ANOTHER
dialogues.text: Let them burn. What needs telephones? A chorus of agreement, not excited this time, but deep an LAWRENCE rises, pounding the table again, breaks in, cryi desperately:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: The need is absolute!

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Then we need the English engineers.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: No! Take English engineers and you take English Government! Take --- The door bursts open and a dishevelled SHEIK and SYRIAN b A mob of yelling petitioners attempts to follow and is be the BODYGUARD who close the door. The SYRIAN screeches ou to the others at the far end of the table:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: j oO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 875 Continued

dialogues.speaker: . DISHEVELLED SYRIAN
dialogues.text: Fire! (He fights for breath) Fire has broken out! (He fights for breath again, makes a graphic gesture with both hands) All along the waterfront!

dialogues.speaker: H-108
dialogues.text: The SYRIANS start to their feet in an overlapping clamour "In what quarter?" 'In what district?" exploding and fall in the same instant.

dialogues.speaker: L DISHEVELLED SYRIAN
dialogues.text: The Jinsibi District!

dialogues.speaker: FIRST SYRIAN
dialogues.text: (to LAWRENCE, reassuringly) It is not a district that matters.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (looking at him with cool dislike) It. will spread.

dialogues.speaker: SECOND SYRIAN
dialogues.text: (between exasperation at the stupidity of the savages and alarm for his property) Then in God's name, use the fire brigade!

dialogues.speaker: DISHEVELLED SHEIK
dialogues.text: We have tried, Aurens. Thereis no... (He makes desperate pushing movements with his hands as he seeks for the word "pressure") . no force in the water.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (almost stamping) Then you must carry it!

dialogues.speaker: DISHEVELLED SHEIK
dialogues.text: (with dignity) The Rualla do not carry water.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (in the spirit of sheer mischief) What else are they good for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ii-109 Continued There is an uproar again, some laughing, the Rualla and t furious, and the others quick to respond. MUSIC (Arab the mounting) LAWRENCE rises, gesturing DISHEVELLED SHEIK to follow him. The doors are thrown open, and under the risi the petitioners pour in, waving papers, beseeching, bully or tearful. We see that they extend throughout the lobby Hall towards the open double doorway. CLOSE SHOT. ONE OF THE SHEIKS at the table is stuffing si ink stands into the fold of his garment, hurriedly, as on to depart. MEDIUM.SHOT. On the steps of the Town Hall, LAWRENCE is shouting into the uproar.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: We will hear petitions this afternoon! This afternoon ... LONG SHOT. In the street or square outside the Town Hall on its side. And people run from every quarter towards th the Town Hall where we see LAWRENCE fighting forwards thr intemperately individual mob, a hopeless enterprise. cuT ALLENBY'S ROOM. CLOSE SHOT. BRIGHTON stands stiff and uneasy by one ot the windows, biting his lip looking out sky with a faint red glow in it from which distant shouts occasional scream are also heard. He turns to look at: MEDIUM SHOT. The electric light is burning. Bottles, glas and used plates. DRYDEN sits at his ease, reading. ALLENB has one eye upon an open book upon a table and, in a high stance with one leg before the other, he holds aloft a pi with a length of string attached to it, EXTREME CLOSE SHOT. It is a text book on fly fishing and shows an Edwardian gentleman in knickerbockers going thro motions of a cast. CLOSE SHOT. ALLENBY dutifully performs the motions as dec there. He seems totally absorbed.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (murmuring) I'm going to take this up after the war...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Il-110 Continued

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (bursting out) Surely we should do something, sir? DRYDEN looks up at him over his spectacles, but ALLENBY i it totally, murmuring:

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: It's an old man's sport...

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (with dry and admiring mockery) Are you an old man, sir?

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (absently, eye on the diagram) Mm ..7 .

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (hotly) Well all I can say is, sir -- it's a heavy responsibility: ALLENBY directs a look of venomous resentment at him.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: (awkwardly) Sorry, sir... The light goes off, putting them in moonlight and showing beyond one of the windows. We see that the torpor of DRYD ALLENBY was more apparent than real, and ALLENBY has laid his rod before BRIGHTON has fully registered what's happe

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: It may be the bulb. DRYDEN clicks the switch of a reading lamp off and on.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: No, sir, it's the power. ys As he is saying this we hear the jingle and thud of horse window. They go quickly onto the balcony and look down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MEDIUM SHOT ANGLING DOWN. A caravan of mixed horse and camel riders, veiled, silent, inscrutable, they lead lade at their sides.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (an excited whisper) They're leaving sir.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: That's it then. Marvellous looking beggars, aren't they? (he looks down intently, curiously regretful) cuT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOWN HALL INTERIOR. The room is lit by many candles, some in lovely candelabra, some in saucers; the table is litte cups. SHEIK is asleep. AUDA sits opposite LAWRENCE. Both table and floor are littered with papers. ALI and LAWRENCE sit where they did before. LAWRENCE is writing and AUDA The OLD i watches him with displeasure. Suddenly his hand descends paper. Leave it, Aurens! LAWRENCE makes no attempt to retrieve the paper.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: AUDA blankly and mildly:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Come where?

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (with a jerk of the head) Back ... I know you heart. Come with met He looks at , LAWRENCE gently extracts the paper and apparently returns attention to it. What is it? AUDA watches as before.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Is it this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 387 388 Tt-112 Continued He contemptuously indicates the room with its littered pa : AUDA (cont) I tell you this is nothing. LAWRENCE goes on writing. He is very moved. AUDA rises an walks down the room to the door, passing ALI who is all e does not move anerve. At the door, AUDA pauses.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA -
dialogues.text: Is it... the blood? CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. AUDA continues on SOUND TRACK, warm, confident, comforting. I tell you the desert has dried up more blood than you could think of. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. AUDA in background. LAWRENCE shows no facial emotion. Deadpan, he raises one hand and deliberate formality:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: I pray I may never see the desert again. Hear me God.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Well will you come... EXTREME CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. On SOUND TRACK AUDA says: ... there is only the desert for you. On SOUND TRACK we hear the door open and shut. Immediatel LAWRENCE raises his head and sees ALI looking at him down table. He goes back to his work for a space, then:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: What about you, Ali? CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. ALI in background.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: No, I shall stay here. And learn politics. LAWRENCE hesitates, stops writing, but does not look up.  388 389 390 391 392

dialogues.speaker: T-113
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: That's a very low occupation.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: I had not thought of it when I met you. CLOSE SHOT. ALI rises not purposely but compelled, and fi himself on his feet, knows he is making a farewell. He he glancing down the table at his friend. LONG SHOT. FROM ALI'S POINT OF VIEW. LAWRENCE is seemingly absorbed in paper.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: (half resentful, almost accusing) You have tried very hard to give us Damascus? After a pause to control himself, LAWRENCE says mildly:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: It's what I came for. REVERSE SHOT FROM HIS VIEWPOINT. ALI by the door.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: And then . (ALI turns quickly) .+. it would be something ... ? It is a naked appeal.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Yes. (He tries for a smile) Much. LAWRENCE half-smiles back, but as they raise their hands when the ship is already too far fromthe shore and friend parting already complete, and themselves already stranger ALI goes through the door. MEDIUM SHOT. Down the corridor which he has entered. It i only by moonlight which pours through the arch windows wh punctuate one wall, This wall ends with an open archway t which the moonlight also prurs. The corridor is thus in a

dialogues.speaker: T-114
dialogues.text: 392 Continued bands of silver light and grey shadows. From one of these a MAN steps silently and grasps him by the arm. He instin recoils but finds himself gripped.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (After a moment’s silence: Accusing) He is your friend? At this, ALI immediately sets off down the corridor, his

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Take your -hand away.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (Ignoring this) You love him.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: No, I fear him. AUDA's face is angled so that we can see it; ALI's face i shadow of his headcloth save for bright lights on his eye peers a little.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Then why do you weep? This is said certainly not as a sneer, and certainly not sympathy, but as men speak of weeping naturally whose vir beyond question. There is a moment or two of silence befo reply.

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: If I fear him ... who love him... How must he fear himself, who hates himself? (Suddenly all the emotion comes pouring through and ALI shouts furiously) Take your hand away ... ALI wrenches himself free with a cat-like bound, simultan drawing his dagger which (CLOSE SHOT) carves a bright arc gloom. --» Howeitat!

dialogues.speaker: W-115
dialogues.text: Continued AUDA has made the minimum necessary movement to avoid the instinctively, and now regards ALI, unruffled and even pl is leaning one hand against the wall.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: (grinning) ' O-h-h-. You're not entirely politician. ALI is sheathing his knife, but looks up at this and says

dialogues.speaker: ALI
dialogues.text: Not yet. They have come to an open archway. CUT to the courtyard. ALI is crossing it diagonally towards a far corner where shadows is another archway. CLOSE SHOT. AUDA, his face turned up to the moon and star

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Well these are new tricks ... (Complacently) and I am an old dog. He stretches luxuriously and breathes in the open air.

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Allah be thanked. He lowers his head and watches ALI, who is entering the s calls: I tell thee what though ... ! REVERSE SHOT. ALI in the shadows turns back towards AUDA. AUDA is calling under the stars:

dialogues.speaker: AUDA
dialogues.text: Being an "Arab", will be thornier than you suppose --- Harith!

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE SHOT. The indignant face of BRITISH COLONEL Glares straight into CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: a
Continued

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: In all my years as a Medical Officer, I've never seen anything like it! MEDIUM SHOT. ALLENBY confronts him. He has just risen fro bed and is wrapping on his dressing gown. We see that he immediate action. It is broad morning.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: It comes within the jurisdiction of the Arab Council.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, sir. Under the circumstances I think I must take over immediately.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY -
dialogues.text: (almost automatically) Under any circumstances at all you must _obey your orders.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: No, sir, I will not!

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (not angered by the insubordination, irritated by the excess emotion’. Contemptuously) Control yourself. (Then) Now, go over to the Town Hall and see what they say.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE looking straight up into CAMERA, and the CUT so timed that he appears to be speaki response to ALLENBY 's line.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (Totally exhausted, quite simple) I had forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: Had you indeed!
ie LY

dialogues.speaker: W-117
dialogues.text: Continued

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (as one who offers useless exculpation) We did what we could in the civic hospitals ...

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: But you "forgot" the Turkish Military Hospital!

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (fearfully) Are there many? Yes.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL
dialogues.text: It has six hundred beds. There are about two thousand Turkish wounded init. All of whom are the responsibility of your precious Arab Council; and many of whom are your responsibility inmore ways than that, I understand:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (cannot look at him) Yes. Sad MUSIC begins, and he rises. Then, as one who fears th to his question, he asks: . . What's it like? cur MEDIUM LONG SHOT. MUSIC CONTINUING. The courtyard of the Turkish Military Hospital. The beds are overflowed in courtyard. Here and there tarpaulin awnings have been rig one of these, over the hospital entrance, has come loose corner and flaps heavily and slowly with a soft insidious REVERSE SHOT. and the horrible buzzing of flies. courtyard at the far side. From under this flapping awning. We hear it LAWRENCE has entered the CLOSE TRACKING SHOT: Moving with LAWRENCE among the patients. Some are dead. They are unwashed, their bandage are blood caked, dirty dressings and enamel containers li (But the CAMERA must not linger on any one thing; we must all passing; we want to establish a faci, not assault the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If-118 MEDIUM SHOT. Having tracked with LAWRENCE to the awning a the entrance, we pause with him. Voices croak "Water"... +++ monotonously. The Turkish word is used so that we do understand it, until LAWRENCE, coming to, snatches up an water jug and darts into the hospital. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. He searches frantically down a corri also littered with patients, catching glimpses inside war contents. He comes to a dispensary and darts in. Frantica turns atap. The MUSIC rising hopefully. EXTREME CLOSE SHOT. THE TAP. No water is init. MUSIC dies away to silence. CLOSE SHOT. He puts down the jug. He leans back against t dispensary shelves. His wandering eye lights upon a broom picks it up, and as he does so, we hear cars drawing up, slamming and crisp voices shouting instructions. MEDIUM LONG SHOT. THE COURTYARD. Army ambulances are drawing up and drawn up. MEDICAL OFFICERS, NURSING SISTER and ORDERLIES are fanning out between the beds. Stretcher being unloaded. Already we can see SIX DOCTORS, a DOZEN SISTERS and a SCORE OF ORDERLIES. They are clean, starche competent. It is like a vision of heaven. MEDIUM LONG SHOT. ANGLING DOWN A WARD. LAWRENCE in foreground, is studiously sweeping between the bunks. A m and very military M.O. attended by TWO ORDERLIES marches long ward. He stops at LAWRENCE. He is the Captain of the School, the Chairman of the Golf Club. His face is crimso enormous and fleshy.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: This is... is... outrageous! (he is enjoying it) Outrageous! Outrageous! (he comes up to LAWRENCE) Outrageous! CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. The pale ghost of his old mockery haunts his features once again. He begins to laugh. The M OFFICER stares incredulously, then deals him such a full- smack across his face as flings him from. his feet agains

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: (carelessly, as he strides out) Filthy little wog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 409 410 411 Ti-119 CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE crouched against the wall continues laugh. (And let there be no mistake, but that it is laugh it may remind one of tears. The only thing no audience co possibly accept from this strange man ~ particularly at t is acy pity. Which would also quite ruinously "explain" h mind)

dialogues.speaker: QUICK DISSOLVE
dialogues.text: CLOSE SHOT. FEISAL in all the panoply of an Arabian King, speaking, melodiously, persuasively, gently and humorousl he speaks, CAMERA DRAWS AWAY to reveal that he is in ALLENBY's great room in Damascus. This is his prestige ro not his. working office; polished furniture, royal portra treatment. ALLENBY is seated at an enormous and useless d Behind and to one side of him DRYDEN is seated, regarding clasped hands; behind again, BRIGHTON stands, looking as ALLENBY, towards the object of FEISAL's discourse whom we yet see.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: My friend Lawrence, if I may call him that -- "my friend Lawrence" -- how many men will claim the right to use that phrase, how proudly! He longs for the greenness of his native land. He pines for the Gothic cottages of -- "Surrey" =~ is it not? (he smiles a little at ‘his own pretentions to be familiar with all that) Already in imagination he catches trout and... all the activities of the English gentleman. MEDIUM CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE looks silently back at him without judgment, without even distaste, almost as though only just met him. Now and henceforth 90% of LAWRENCE's e is taken in merely sustaining the burden of his own natur only 10% for dealings with the outer world. He listens ca politely to everything, and reacts to nothing. And this i but a necessary economy to which he is committed. Any sug attitudenising would be very distasteful at this point. H cerned not to be any kind of nuisance. It is simply that elementary good manners are all that he can possibly mana ALLENBY coughs uncomfortably in the silence.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: That's me you're describing, sir, not Colonel Lawrence...

dialogues.speaker: L
dialogues.text: oO] ‘ Il-120 411. Continued ALLENBY (Cont) (roughly, looking up at LAWRENCE and quickly down again) You're promoted Colonel,

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Yes. What for? (He asks the question with polite interest not aggressively)

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (quickly) Take the honour, Colonel. Be a little kind.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: (roughly) As a Colonel you'll have a cabin to yourself on the boat home.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: (a flicker of real interest) Then thank you. There is another awkward pause. ALLENBY aligns some paper Then he forces himself to look at LAWRENCE, chin out and ruthlessly:

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Well then ... "God speed". FEISAL cuts in with quick persuasion.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: There is nothing further for a warrior here. (unreal self-deprecation) We drive bargains. LAWRENCE looks at him, without anger, without condemnatio without comment of any kind. FEISAL is touched with the d comfort, and adds more sincerely: Old men's work. Young men make wars ~~ and virtues of war are the virtues of young men ~- courage and hope for the future. And then old men

dialogues.speaker: I-121
dialogues.text: Continued FEISAL (Cont) make the peace, and the vices of peace are the vices of old men -- mistrust and caution. (gently) It must be so. LAWRENCE simply gets up. He pauses momentarily wondering to do with his cap, or what to say that will get him out Quietly, the others have risen also. Tongue-tied. He goes door and is awkwardly half way through it when he is arre

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (in a different voice, low and quick, not looking at him) What I owe you is beyond evaluation. LAWRENCE completes the closing of the door. CLOSE SHOT. BRIGHTON looks after him, concerned. Concerne for the man, concerned that no more has been made of the On SOUND TRACK we hear ‘a clearing of throats and scrapin as the others reseat themselves.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: The Power House, the Telephone Exchange, these I concede. The Pumping Plant I must retain. BRIGHTON looks at him, horrified and indignant. They face another across the desk like a pair of bargaining peasant

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: If you retain the Pumping Plant there will be no water, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: I shall be glad of any technical assistance.

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: In fairness then, you must bring down your Flag!

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: I shall not bring down my Flag. And if your men attempt it, my men will resist it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 412 Continued p— - ALLENBY Have you any men, sir.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: Enough for that. It is the kind of thing S that makes a very ugly incident. Iam sure your Government does not wish to . appear at the Peace Conference in the light of an aggressor. It is widely known ) the Arab Council took power in my name. '® ALLENBY | (impatiently) They have no power, sir. It’s illusory!

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: oe Illusions can be very powerful. Particularly when they take this form. He rises and lets drop a pile of newspapers on ALLENBY's os 413 EXTREME CLOSE SHOT. THE NEWSPAPERS. They are in oO several languages. The top one is the "Chicago Daily C and there is a reproduction of the photograph taken by BE after the blood-bath. On SOUND TRACK:

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: G (on SOUND TRACK) ‘ The world is delighted with the picture of Damascus liberated by the Arab Army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: © ALLENBY Led, may I remind you, by a British serving Officer!

dialogues.speaker: _ FEISAL
dialogues.text: C (a small smile) : Ah yes. But then Aurens is a sword with two edges. We are equally glad to be rid of him are we not?

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: ~~, (between admiration I \ and disgust) el I thought I was a hard man.  414

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: soON

dialogues.speaker: VA

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: You are merely a General. I must be a King. He speaks with an archaic dignity which puts several cent between them. But CLOSE SHOT BRIGHTON. Indignantly, he ra his hat on his head, salutes, says:

dialogues.speaker: BRIGHTON
dialogues.text: 'Scuse me, sir... And strides from the room without waiting for permission, LAWRENCE. ALLENBY looks after him rather wryly, then, his guilt causing him to anticipate an attack, he half turns towards DRYDEN and barks almost snarls, aggressively:

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Well? DRYDEN in fact was examining his fingers as before, but a too fires and out of his guilt, says with bitter brightne

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Well it seems we're to have a British Water Works, with an Arab Flag on it. (to both) D'you ‘think it was worth it?

dialogues.speaker: ALLENBY
dialogues.text: Not my business. Thank God, I'ma soldier.

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: (murmuring) Yes, sir: so you keep saying.

dialogues.speaker: FEISAL
dialogues.text: (to DRYDEN) You, I suspect, are chief architect of this ... (he chooses the word delicately) compromise. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DRYDEN
dialogues.text: Me, your Highness? On the whole, I wish I'd stayed in Tunbridge Wells.

dialogues.text: 417 i f ey

dialogues.speaker: II-124
dialogues.text: LAWRENCE is crossing the Officer's Lounge in the Damascus Headquarters. A few OFFICERS sit about, mostly reading pa LAWRENCE absently puts on his cap, and hastily takes it o CLOSE SHOT. The red-faced MEDICAL OFFICER springs from his chair as LAWRENCE walks past him.

dialogues.speaker: ' MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: I say! LAWRENCE turns and flinches when he sees who itis. The MEDICAL OFFICER advances on him.

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: It's Colonel Lawrence, isn't it? LAWRENCE nods. Well may I shake your hand, sir? He does so, chuckling apologetically, without help from L Then he steps back at attention, and says with manly ferv

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Just want to be able to say I've done it, sir. LAWRENCE is going, and then turns back to say, not lightl with deep and serious curiosity:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE
dialogues.text: Haven't. we met before?

dialogues.speaker: MEDICAL OFFICER
dialogues.text: Growning) _Den't think so, sir... (smiling confidently) No, sir, I should have remembered that. curt rm MEDIUM SHOT ANGLING UP a flight of narrow stairs. BRIGHTO appears quickly at the head of them and descends two at a pushes open a pair of double doors and walks rapidly thro office. He appears through a door into a little courtyard it and in through another door. He appears in the Officer walking swiftly through it in the same direction as that LAWRENCE. He runs through the Icbby on to the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 418 419 420 421 422 1-125 CLOSE SHOT. He looks eagerly up and down the drive. The eagerness dies away from his face; he looks crestfallen, downright gloomy. cuT THE ROAD from Damascus in the after-glow of sunset. It is desert. CAMERA is in rear of a travelling staff car. In t are the DRIVER and LAWRENCE. There is no sound but the wi and the engine. An Army lorry passes us in the opposite d then the staff car must slow down for a file of BEDOUIN o going in the same direction. CLOSE SHOT. LAWRENCE. He stands and peers up hopefully into their faces as the car crawls past. MEDIUM TRACKING SHOT. P.O.V. LAWRENCE. Their faces. They show no sign of recognition. We hear the car acceler and accelerating, we leave them behind in our dust. CLOSE TRACKING SHOT. The DRIVER and, obscured by him so that in this last moment he is hidden, LAWRENCE. , ee

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Well, sir, going home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car purrs onwards.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE . 4
dialogues.text: (realising that he has been addressed) Mm?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Home, sir! : LAWRENCE does not answer by word or expression. The level desert swings endlessly past us. A second Army lorry appr and swings past us, full of Tommies singing a music-hail the period. (‘Goodbye Dolly, I must leave you...) The sou their singing disappears swiftly behind us and immediatel Dispatch Rider on a motor bicycle passes in the same dire We glimpse the RIDER and the screen is enveloped in the d his machine throws upwards.
